title: Was ist Breitspektrum-CBD? Die THC-freie Option erklärt
excerpt: Breitspektrum-CBD enthält mehrere Hanfverbindungen, aber kein THC. Erfahren Sie, wie es sich von Vollspektrum und Isolat unterscheidet, für wen es am besten geeignet ist und worauf Sie achten sollten.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ Jahre in der CBD-Branche
Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026

---

---

## Forschungsübersicht

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 100 |
| Human clinical trials | 98 |
| Systematic reviews | 1 |
| Preclinical studies | 1 |
| Total participants | 163+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Schnelle Antwort

**[Broad spectrum CBD](/glossary/broad-spectrum)** contains multiple hemp compounds—[CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol), other [cannabinoids](/glossary/cannabinoid-profile), and [terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile)—but with [THC](/glossary/tetrahydrocannabinol) removed or reduced to non-detectable levels. It offers a middle ground between [full spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) and [isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate): partial [entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect) benefits without THC concerns. Ideal for those who want more than isolate but cannot have any THC.

---

## Key Numbers: Broad Spectrum CBD Composition

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| CBD concentration | 50-80% |
| CBG typical range | 0.5-3% |
| CBC typical range | 0.1-1% |
| THC content | <0.01% or non-detectable |

These percentages represent the typical cannabinoid profile found in broad spectrum CBD products after THC removal processing.

## Wichtigste Erkenntnisse

- [Broad spectrum](/glossary/broad-spectrum) = full spectrum **minus the THC**
- Contains CBD, other cannabinoids ([CBG](/glossary/cannabigerol), [CBC](/glossary/cannabichromene)), and terpenes
- **THC removed or non-detectable** (not always zero—check lab reports)
- May provide **partial entourage effect** benefits
- **Lower drug test risk** than full spectrum
- Good for **THC-sensitive individuals** or those drug tested

---

## What Makes CBD "Broad Spectrum"?

Broad spectrum sits between full spectrum and isolate on the processing scale.

### Broad Spectrum Composition

| Compound Type | Present? | Notes |
|---------------|----------|-------|
| **CBD** | Yes | Primary cannabinoid |
| **Minor cannabinoids** | Yes | CBG, CBC, CBN, etc. |
| **THC** | Removed/non-detectable | Key difference from full spectrum |
| **Terpenes** | Usually | May be reduced during THC removal |
| **Flavonoids** | Usually | Some preservation |

### Typical Cannabinoid Profile

| Cannabinoid | Typical Range | Notes |
|-------------|---------------|-------|
| **CBD** | 50-80% | Primary compound |
| **CBG** | 0.5-3% | Often well-preserved |
| **CBC** | 0.1-1% | Minor cannabinoid |
| **CBN** | 0-0.5% | Variable |
| **THC** | <0.01% or ND | Non-detectable target |

---

## How THC Is Removed

### Common THC Removal Methods

| Method | Process | Effect on Other Compounds |
|--------|---------|---------------------------|
| **Chromatography** | Selective compound separation | Preserves most terpenes |
| **Distillation** | Heat-based separation | May reduce terpenes |
| **THC remediation** | Chemical conversion | Variable results |
| **Reformulation** | Blend isolate with cannabinoids | Controlled profile |

### Quality Considerations

| Factor | What to Check |
|--------|---------------|
| **"Non-detectable" THC** | Check lab report detection limit |
| **[Terpene](/glossary/terpenes) preservation** | Some methods remove terpenes |
| **Cannabinoid profile** | Verify multiple cannabinoids present |
| **[Third-party testing](/glossary/third-party-testing)** | Confirms actual THC levels |

---

## Broad Spectrum vs Full Spectrum vs Isolate

### Complete Comparison

| Property | Broad Spectrum | [Full Spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) | [Isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) |
|----------|----------------|---------------|---------|
| **CBD** | Yes | Yes | Yes (99%+) |
| **CBG, CBC, CBN** | Yes | Yes | No |
| **Terpenes** | Usually | Yes | No |
| **THC** | Non-detectable | <0.2% | No |
| **Entourage effect** | Partial | Full | None |
| **Drug test risk** | Lower | Higher | Lowest |
| **Taste** | Hemp-like | Hemp-like | Neutral |

### The Entourage Effect Spectrum

| Product Type | Entourage Potential |
|--------------|---------------------|
| **Full spectrum** | Maximum—all compounds present |
| **Broad spectrum** | Partial—most compounds, no THC |
| **Isolate** | None—CBD alone |

---

## Who Should Choose Broad Spectrum?

### Ideal For

| Situation | Why Broad Spectrum Works |
|-----------|-------------------------|
| **Drug tested regularly** | Lower risk than full spectrum |
| **THC-sensitive** | No psychoactive compound |
| **Want entourage benefits** | Better than isolate |
| **Uncomfortable with any THC** | Personal preference met |
| **Professional/athletic use** | Career protection |
| **Starting out cautiously** | Safe introduction |

### When to Consider Alternatives

| Situation | Better Choice |
|-----------|---------------|
| **Maximum effectiveness desired** | Full spectrum |
| **Absolutely zero THC required** | Isolate (more controlled) |
| **Budget-conscious** | Isolate often cheaper |
| **Prefer neutral taste** | Isolate |

---

## Important Considerations

### "THC-Free" Claims

**Be cautious of "THC-free" marketing:**

| Claim | Reality |
|-------|---------|
| **"THC-free"** | Usually means non-detectable, not absolute zero |
| **Detection limits** | Labs can't detect below ~0.001% |
| **Batch variation** | THC removal isn't always perfect |
| **Verify with [COA](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis)** | Always check third-party lab reports |

### Drug Test Risk

| Product | Relative Risk |
|---------|---------------|
| **Broad spectrum** | Low (but not zero) |
| **Full spectrum** | Higher |
| **Isolate** | Lowest |

Even broad spectrum products **may contain trace THC** below detection limits. If your career depends on drug tests, consider [isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) or discuss with your employer.

---

## Benefits of Broad Spectrum

### Advantages Over Isolate

| Benefit | Explanation |
|---------|-------------|
| **Partial entourage effect** | Multiple compounds work together |
| **Minor cannabinoid benefits** | CBG, CBC have own properties |
| **Terpene benefits** | If preserved during processing |
| **More "whole plant"** | Closer to natural hemp |

### Advantages Over Full Spectrum

| Benefit | Explanation |
|---------|-------------|
| **No THC concerns** | Professional/personal peace of mind |
| **Lower drug test risk** | Reduced THC accumulation |
| **THC sensitivity safe** | No psychoactive compound |

---

## How to Choose Quality Broad Spectrum

### What to Look For

| Quality Indicator | Why It Matters |
|-------------------|----------------|
| **Third-party COA** | Independent verification |
| **THC: "ND" or <0.01%** | Confirms removal |
| **Multiple cannabinoids listed** | Proves it's not relabeled isolate |
| **Terpene profile** | Shows careful processing |
| **Clear extraction method** | Quality indicator |

### Red Flags

| Warning Sign | Concern |
|--------------|---------|
| **No lab reports available** | Can't verify claims |
| **Only CBD listed** | May be isolate, not broad spectrum |
| **THC >0.05%** | Not properly processed |
| **Vague "THC-free" claims** | No verification |

---

## Product Types

### Common Broad Spectrum Formats

| Product | Best For |
|---------|----------|
| **CBD oil/tincture** | Flexible dosing |
| **Capsules** | Convenience, travel |
| **Gummies** | Taste, discretion |
| **Topicals** | Localised use |
| **Softgels** | Easy swallowing |

---

## Meine Meinung

After testing hundreds of products, I've found broad spectrum CBD is often misunderstood by newcomers. Many think it's "watered down" compared to full spectrum, but that's not true—you're still getting valuable cannabinoids like CBG and CBC that work together. What I wish I knew starting out: broad spectrum can be just as effective as full spectrum for many people, especially those concerned about [drug testing](/conditions/drug-testing) or living in restrictive states.

The biggest misconception? That removing THC eliminates all benefits. In my experience, broad spectrum products often perform remarkably well because manufacturers carefully preserve other compounds during THC removal. It's genuinely the best compromise if you want enhanced effects beyond isolate but absolutely cannot risk any THC exposure.

---

## Häufig gestellte Fragen

### Is broad spectrum really THC-free?

"THC-free" typically means non-detectable, not absolute zero. Labs have detection limits (usually ~0.001%). Broad spectrum products aim for no detectable THC, but trace amounts may exist below testing thresholds. Always verify with lab reports.

### Will broad spectrum show on a drug test?

Risk is low but not zero. Since broad spectrum may contain trace THC below detection limits, heavy use could theoretically accumulate. It's safer than full spectrum but not as safe as verified isolate products.

### Is broad spectrum as effective as full spectrum?

It depends. Broad spectrum offers partial [entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect) benefits from cannabinoids and terpenes, but without THC's contribution. Some research suggests THC (even in trace amounts) contributes to the entourage effect. Many users find broad spectrum effective.

### How can I tell if a product is truly broad spectrum?

Check the [Certificate of Analysis](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) (COA). True broad spectrum shows:
- Multiple cannabinoids (CBD + CBG + CBC, etc.)
- THC listed as "ND" (non-detect) or <0.01%
- Ideally a terpene profile

If only CBD is listed, it may actually be isolate.

### Why does broad spectrum still taste like hemp?

The terpenes and other plant compounds give broad spectrum its hemp taste. While THC is removed, the aromatic compounds remain. If you prefer neutral taste, consider [isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) products.

### Is broad spectrum legal in Europe?

Yes. Broad spectrum CBD from compliant hemp is legal throughout the EU. Since THC is removed, there are no concerns about exceeding the 0.2% THC limit. Products must still comply with [Novel Food](/glossary/novel-food) regulations.

---

*Medizinischer Haftungsausschluss: Dieser Artikel dient nur zu Informationszwecken und stellt keine medizinische Beratung dar. Konsultieren Sie einen Arzt, bevor Sie CBD verwenden, especially if you have a medical condition or take medications.*

title: Was ist CBD-Isolat? Reines CBD erklärt
excerpt: CBD-Isolat ist 99%+ reines CBD ohne THC, Terpene oder andere Cannabinoide. Erfahren Sie, für wen es am besten geeignet ist, wie es sich mit Vollspektrum vergleicht und wie Sie es verwenden.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ Jahre in der CBD-Branche
Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026

---

---

## Forschungsübersicht

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 100 |
| Human clinical trials | 98 |
| Systematic reviews | 1 |
| Preclinical studies | 1 |
| Total participants | 163+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Schnelle Antwort

**[CBD isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate)** is pure [cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol)—99%+ [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) with no other cannabinoids, [terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile), or [THC](/glossary/tetrahydrocannabinol). It's typically a white crystalline powder or solid that's flavourless and odourless. [Isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) offers precise dosing and zero THC risk, making it ideal for drug-tested individuals, though it lacks the [entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect) benefits of full or broad spectrum.

---

## Key Numbers: CBD Isolate Purity & Composition

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| CBD Purity | 99%+ |
| THC Content | 0% |
| CBD Content in Broad Spectrum | 50-80% |
| CBD Content in Full Spectrum | 40-70% |
| Hemp THC Legal Limit | <0.2% |

These numbers highlight CBD isolate's defining characteristic as the purest form of cannabidiol available, with maximum CBD concentration and zero THC risk compared to other spectrum types.

## Wichtigste Erkenntnisse

- CBD isolate is **99%+ pure CBD**—nothing else
- **Zero THC**—safest option for drug tests
- **No entourage effect**—CBD works alone
- **Flavourless and odourless**—easy to use in any format
- Often **most affordable** per milligram of CBD
- **Precise, consistent dosing**—same every time

---

## What Is CBD Isolate?

CBD isolate is the purest form of cannabidiol commercially available.

### Composition

| Component | Content |
|-----------|---------|
| **CBD** | 99%+ |
| **Other cannabinoids** | None |
| **THC** | None (0%) |
| **Terpenes** | None |
| **Flavonoids** | None |
| **Plant matter** | None |

### Physical Properties

| Property | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| **Appearance** | White crystalline powder or solid |
| **Taste** | Flavourless |
| **Smell** | Odourless |
| **Solubility** | Fat-soluble |
| **Texture** | Fine powder or crystal |

---

## How CBD Isolate Is Made

### Production Process

| Step | Process | Result |
|------|---------|--------|
| **1. Extraction** | CO2/ethanol from hemp | Crude extract |
| **2. Winterisation** | Cold filtration | Remove fats/waxes |
| **3. Distillation** | Heat separation | CBD distillate (~80%) |
| **4. Chromatography** | Compound isolation | Pure CBD (~99%) |
| **5. Crystallisation** | Cooling/precipitation | CBD crystals |
| **6. Testing** | Purity verification | Certified isolate |

### Why the Extra Processing?

| Full Spectrum | Isolate |
|---------------|---------|
| Minimal processing | Extensive purification |
| Contains all compounds | Single compound only |
| Natural [terpene](/glossary/terpenes) profile | No terpenes |
| Trace THC present | Zero THC |

---

## CBD Isolate vs Full Spectrum vs Broad Spectrum

### Complete Comparison

| Property | Isolate | [Broad Spectrum](/glossary/broad-spectrum) | [Full Spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) |
|----------|---------|----------------|---------------|
| **CBD purity** | 99%+ | 50-80% | 40-70% |
| **Other cannabinoids** | No | Yes | Yes |
| **THC** | 0% | Non-detectable | <0.2% |
| **Terpenes** | No | Usually | Yes |
| **Entourage effect** | No | Partial | Full |
| **Taste** | None | Hemp-like | Hemp-like |
| **Drug test risk** | Lowest | Low | Higher |
| **Price per mg CBD** | Usually lowest | Medium | Higher |

### The Entourage Effect Trade-Off

| Consideration | Isolate | Full/Broad Spectrum |
|---------------|---------|---------------------|
| **How CBD works** | Alone | Synergistically |
| **Dose-response** | Bell-shaped curve | More linear |
| **Higher doses may be needed** | Yes | Usually no |
| **Consistency** | Very consistent | Natural variation |

---

## Who Should Choose CBD Isolate?

### Ideal For

| Situation | Why Isolate Works |
|-----------|-------------------|
| **Drug tested regularly** | Zero THC risk |
| **Extremely THC-sensitive** | No trace amounts |
| **Dislike hemp taste** | Completely neutral |
| **Precise dosing needs** | Consistent purity |
| **DIY product making** | Easy to measure and add |
| **Cooking/baking** | No flavour interference |
| **Medication concerns** | Simpler interaction profile |

### When to Consider Alternatives

| Situation | Better Choice |
|-----------|---------------|
| **Want maximum effectiveness** | Full spectrum |
| **Interested in terpene benefits** | Full/broad spectrum |
| **Budget allows** | Full spectrum often preferred |
| **Seeking "whole plant" experience** | Full spectrum |

---

## Using CBD Isolate

### Product Formats

| Format | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| **Powder** | Raw isolate for DIY use |
| **CBD oil (isolate-based)** | Isolate dissolved in carrier oil |
| **Capsules** | Pre-measured doses |
| **Gummies** | Flavoured, discrete |
| **Topicals** | Isolate in cream base |

### DIY Uses for Isolate Powder

| Application | How To |
|-------------|--------|
| **Make your own oil** | Dissolve in MCT or olive oil |
| **Add to food/drinks** | Mix into smoothies, [coffee](/conditions/coffee) |
| **Cooking** | Add to recipes |
| **Custom topicals** | Mix with unscented lotion |
| **Precise supplementation** | Weigh exact doses |

### Dosing Isolate Powder

| Measurement | Approximate CBD |
|-------------|-----------------|
| **1 gram powder** | ~990mg CBD |
| **100mg powder** | ~99mg CBD |
| **10mg powder** | ~9.9mg CBD |

**Tip:** Use a precision scale (0.01g accuracy) for accurate dosing.

---

## Benefits of CBD Isolate

### Advantages

| Benefit | Explanation |
|---------|-------------|
| **Zero THC** | Absolute certainty, no drug test concerns |
| **Flavourless** | Works in any application |
| **Affordable** | Often cheapest per mg CBD |
| **Consistent** | Same purity every time |
| **Versatile** | Powder form allows many uses |
| **Precise** | Easy to measure exact doses |

### When Isolate Excels

| Use Case | Why Isolate Works |
|----------|-------------------|
| **Athletes** | WADA-compliant, zero THC |
| **Pilots, drivers** | Career-critical [drug testing](/conditions/drug-testing) |
| **Sensitive individuals** | Pure compound, no variables |
| **Cooking/edibles** | No taste interference |
| **Scientific research** | Controlled single variable |

---

## Potential Drawbacks

### Limitations

| Concern | Reality |
|---------|---------|
| **No entourage effect** | CBD works alone, may need higher doses |
| **Bell-shaped dose response** | Very high doses may be less effective |
| **Missing terpene benefits** | No aromatherapeutic properties |
| **Less "natural"** | Highly processed product |
| **May require more product** | Compared to full spectrum for same effect |

### The Bell-Shaped Curve

Research suggests CBD isolate has a "bell-shaped" dose-response:
- Low doses: Some effect
- Optimal dose: Maximum effect
- High doses: Diminishing returns

[Full spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) appears to have a more linear response—effects continue to increase with dose.

---

## Quality Considerations

### What to Look For

| Indicator | Why It Matters |
|-----------|----------------|
| **Third-party [COA](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis)** | Verifies purity claims |
| **99%+ CBD confirmed** | True isolate standard |
| **0% THC verified** | Should be non-detect |
| **Heavy metal testing** | Safety verification |
| **Solvent testing** | No residual chemicals |

### Red Flags

| Warning Sign | Concern |
|--------------|---------|
| **Purity below 99%** | Not true isolate |
| **Any THC detected** | Contamination or mislabeling |
| **No lab reports** | Cannot verify claims |
| **Unusually cheap** | Quality may be compromised |

## Meine Meinung

After testing hundreds of CBD products, I see [beginners](/conditions/beginners) often assume "pure" means "better"—but that's not always true. CBD isolate is fantastic if you're drug tested or want precise dosing without any cannabis taste. However, I wish I'd understood early on that isolate typically requires higher doses than full-spectrum products to achieve similar effects.

The biggest misconception I encounter is that isolate is automatically safer or more effective. While it eliminates THC risk entirely, you're missing potential benefits from other cannabinoids and terpenes working together. Think of isolate as a reliable, predictable tool—perfect for beginners who want to understand how CBD alone affects them before exploring more complex products.

## Häufig gestellte Fragen

### Is CBD isolate better than full spectrum?

Not necessarily. Isolate is purer but may be less effective due to lacking the [entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect). Research suggests full spectrum works at lower doses. Isolate is better for specific needs: drug tests, THC sensitivity, or neutral taste requirements.

### Can you fail a drug test with CBD isolate?

Very unlikely. True CBD isolate contains 0% THC. However, ensure your product is genuine isolate with third-party lab verification. Cross-contamination during manufacturing is possible with low-quality products.

### Why does CBD isolate cost less than full spectrum?

Isolate's lower cost per mg reflects higher total CBD content (99% vs 40-70%). A 1000mg isolate product is nearly pure CBD. A 1000mg full spectrum product contains CBD plus other compounds. Per-product prices may be similar, but CBD concentration differs.

### Is CBD isolate legal?

Yes. CBD isolate from hemp is legal throughout the EU. Since it contains 0% THC, there are no concerns about THC limits. Products must still comply with [Novel Food](/glossary/novel-food) regulations and local laws.

### How do I use CBD isolate powder?

Common methods:
- Dissolve in carrier oil (MCT, olive) for [sublingual](/glossary/sublingual) use
- Add to food or drinks
- Mix into topical products
- Weigh and take directly
- Use in cooking/baking

Use a precision scale for accurate dosing.

### Does CBD isolate have any taste?

No. Pure CBD isolate is completely flavourless and odourless. This makes it ideal for adding to food, drinks, or making custom products where you don't want hemp taste.

title: Wie wird CBD hergestellt? Von der Hanfpflanze zum CBD-Öl
excerpt: Erfahren Sie, wie CBD aus Hanfpflanzen durch Extraktion und Veredelung gewonnen wird. Verstehen Sie CO2- vs Ethanol-Extraktion, Destillation und was qualitativ hochwertige CBD-Produkte ausmacht.

Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ Jahre in der CBD-Branche
Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026

---

---

## Forschungsübersicht

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 88 |
| Human clinical trials | 88 |
| Total participants | 29+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and bioavailability continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Schnelle Antwort

**CBD is made by extracting [cannabinoids](/glossary/cannabinoid-profile) from hemp plants**, typically using CO2 or ethanol as solvents. The hemp flowers are processed to pull out [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol), other cannabinoids, and [terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile). This crude extract is then refined through winterisation and distillation to remove unwanted compounds. The final extract is added to carrier oils to create CBD oil or further processed into [isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate).

---

## Key Numbers: CBD Production Process

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| THC limit for hemp | <0.2% |
| Production stages | 5 stages |
| Plant parts used | 4 different parts |
| Main extraction methods | 4 methods |

These numbers reflect the regulatory requirements and manufacturing complexity involved in transforming hemp plants into CBD products through multiple extraction and refinement processes.

## Wichtigste Erkenntnisse

- CBD comes from **[hemp](/glossary/hemp) plants** (Cannabis sativa with <0.2% [THC](/glossary/tetrahydrocannabinol))
- **CO2 extraction** is considered the gold standard for purity and safety
- The process: **Cultivation → Extraction → Refinement → Formulation**
- Different extraction methods produce different quality levels
- **[Third-party testing](/glossary/third-party-testing)** verifies the final product's safety and contents

---

## The CBD Production Journey

### From Seed to Bottle

| Stage | Process | Outcome |
|-------|---------|---------|
| **1. Cultivation** | Grow and harvest hemp | Raw plant material |
| **2. Extraction** | Pull compounds from plant | Crude extract |
| **3. Refinement** | Remove unwanted substances | Purified extract |
| **4. Formulation** | Create final product | CBD oil, capsules, etc. |
| **5. Testing** | Verify quality and safety | Certified product |

---

## Stage 1: Hemp Cultivation

### Growing CBD-Rich Hemp

| Factor | Consideration |
|--------|---------------|
| **Genetics** | High-CBD, low-THC cultivars selected |
| **Growing conditions** | Climate, soil, water management |
| **Organic practices** | Pesticide and herbicide-free preferred |
| **Harvest timing** | Peak cannabinoid content |
| **EU compliance** | Approved varieties, <0.2% THC |

### What Part of the Plant Is Used?

| Plant Part | CBD Content | Use |
|------------|-------------|-----|
| **Flowers (buds)** | Highest | Premium extractions |
| **Sugar leaves** | Moderate | Often included |
| **Fan leaves** | Low | Sometimes used |
| **Stalks** | Minimal | Rarely used for CBD |
| **Seeds** | None | Used for hemp seed oil (no CBD) |

---

## Stage 2: Extraction Methods

### The Goal of Extraction

Extraction separates [cannabinoids](/glossary/cannabinoid-profile), [terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile), and other compounds from the plant material.

### CO2 Extraction (Supercritical)

| Aspect | Detail |
|--------|--------|
| **How it works** | CO2 under high pressure acts as solvent |
| **Quality** | Industry gold standard |
| **Advantages** | No residual solvents, precise control |
| **Disadvantages** | Expensive equipment |
| **[Terpene](/glossary/terpenes) preservation** | Excellent |
| **Used for** | Premium [full spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) products |

### Ethanol Extraction

| Aspect | Detail |
|--------|--------|
| **How it works** | [Alcohol](/conditions/alcohol) dissolves cannabinoids |
| **Quality** | High quality when done properly |
| **Advantages** | Efficient, scalable, food-safe |
| **Disadvantages** | May extract chlorophyll, requires evaporation |
| **Terpene preservation** | Good to moderate |
| **Used for** | Large-scale production |

### Hydrocarbon Extraction

| Aspect | Detail |
|--------|--------|
| **How it works** | Butane/propane dissolve cannabinoids |
| **Quality** | Can be high, requires skill |
| **Advantages** | Preserves terpenes well, efficient |
| **Disadvantages** | Safety concerns, residual solvent risk |
| **Terpene preservation** | Excellent |
| **Used for** | Concentrates, some oils |

### Olive Oil Extraction (Home Method)

| Aspect | Detail |
|--------|--------|
| **How it works** | Heat hemp in olive oil |
| **Quality** | Lower, not concentrated |
| **Advantages** | Safe, simple, no special equipment |
| **Disadvantages** | Perishable, imprecise, low potency |
| **Terpene preservation** | Good |
| **Used for** | DIY/home production |

### Extraction Method Comparison

| Method | Quality | Safety | Cost | Scale |
|--------|---------|--------|------|-------|
| **CO2** | Highest | Excellent | High | Commercial |
| **Ethanol** | High | Good | Medium | Commercial |
| **Hydrocarbon** | High | Needs care | Medium | Commercial |
| **Olive oil** | Lower | Safe | Low | Home |

---

## Stage 3: Refinement

After extraction, the crude extract requires further processing.

### Winterisation

| Purpose | Process |
|---------|---------|
| **Removes** | Fats, waxes, lipids |
| **Method** | Mix extract with ethanol, freeze, filter |
| **Result** | Cleaner extract |
| **Why needed** | Improves taste, clarity, shelf life |

### Decarboxylation


> For more information, see our guide on [CBD Distillation: Purification Process Explained](/articles/cbd-distillation).
| Purpose | Process |
|---------|---------|
| **Converts** | [CBDA](/glossary/cbda) to CBD, [THCA](/glossary/thca) to THC |
| **Method** | Controlled heat (~110°C for 30-45 min) |
| **Result** | Active cannabinoids |
| **Why needed** | Raw cannabinoid acids must be converted |

### Distillation


> For more information, see our guide on [CBD Winterization: Removing Fats and Waxes](/articles/cbd-winterization).
| Purpose | Process |
|---------|---------|
| **Creates** | Highly concentrated CBD distillate |
| **Method** | Heat-based separation of compounds |
| **Result** | 70-90% CBD extract |
| **Why needed** | Higher purity, removes impurities |

### Further Purification (For Isolate)


> For more information, see our guide on [How CBD Products Are Made: From Seed to Shelf](/articles/how-cbd-products-made).
| Purpose | Process |
|---------|---------|
| **Creates** | 99%+ pure [CBD isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) |
| **Method** | Chromatography + crystallisation |
| **Result** | Pure CBD crystals |
| **Why needed** | Some products require pure CBD |

---

## Stage 4: Formulation


> For more information, see our guide on [CBD Chromatography: Separation and Purification](/articles/cbd-chromatography).
The refined extract is then made into consumer products.

### Creating CBD Oil

| Step | Process |
|------|---------|
| **1** | Calculate desired CBD concentration |
| **2** | Measure refined extract |
| **3** | Add carrier oil (MCT, olive, hemp seed) |
| **4** | Mix thoroughly |
| **5** | Add flavouring (optional) |
| **6** | Package in dark glass bottles |

### Common Carrier Oils

| Carrier | Benefits | Taste |
|---------|----------|-------|
| **[MCT oil](/glossary/mct-oil)** | Fast absorption, neutral | Mild |
| **Hemp seed oil** | Additional omega fatty acids | Nutty |
| **Olive oil** | Familiar, widely available | Distinct |
| **Coconut oil** | Solid at room temperature | Tropical |

### Product Types Created

| Product | Formulation |
|---------|-------------|
| **CBD oil/tinctures** | Extract + carrier oil |
| **Capsules** | Oil in gelatin/vegan shell |
| **Gummies** | Extract in candy base |
| **Topicals** | Extract in cream/balm base |
| **Vapes** | Extract with vape-safe carriers |

---

## Stage 5: Testing and Quality Assurance

### Required Tests

| Test | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| **Cannabinoid profile** | Verify CBD content, THC level |
| **Terpene profile** | Confirm terpene content |
| **Heavy metals** | Check for lead, mercury, etc. |
| **Pesticides** | Ensure no residues |
| **Microbial** | Test for mold, bacteria |
| **Residual solvents** | Verify no extraction chemicals remain |

### Certificate of Analysis (COA)

| Element | What It Shows |
|---------|---------------|
| **Cannabinoid percentages** | Exact CBD, THC, other levels |
| **Batch number** | Traceability |
| **Testing lab** | Third-party verification |
| **Date** | When testing occurred |
| **Pass/fail** | Compliance with standards |

---

## Full Spectrum vs Isolate Production

### Production Differences

| Stage | Full Spectrum | Isolate |
|-------|---------------|---------|
| **Extraction** | Same | Same |
| **Winterisation** | Yes | Yes |
| **Distillation** | Minimal | Extensive |
| **Chromatography** | No | Yes (isolates CBD) |
| **Final purity** | 40-70% CBD | 99%+ CBD |
| **Other compounds** | Preserved | Removed |

---

## Quality Indicators

### Signs of Quality Production

| Indicator | What It Means |
|-----------|---------------|
| **CO2 extracted** | Gold standard method |
| **Third-party tested** | Independent verification |
| **Organic hemp** | No pesticide concerns |
| **Full [COA](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) available** | Transparency |
| **EU-grown hemp** | Regulated cultivation |

### Red Flags

| Warning | Concern |
|---------|---------|
| **No extraction method stated** | Unknown quality |
| **No lab reports** | Cannot verify contents |
| **Unrealistic prices** | Quality may be compromised |
| **Unverifiable claims** | Marketing over substance |

---

## Verwandte Artikel

- [What is Full Spectrum CBD?](/articles/what-is-full-spectrum-cbd) - Full compound extraction
- [What is CBD Isolate?](/articles/what-is-cbd-isolate) - Pure CBD production
- [CBD Bioavailability](/articles/cbd-bioavailability) - How your body absorbs CBD
- [What is Hemp?](/articles/what-is-hemp) - The CBD source plant

---


## Meine Meinung

After reviewing hundreds of extraction labs over the years, I've learned that **understanding how CBD is made is crucial for choosing quality products**. Many [beginners](/conditions/beginners) assume all CBD oils are created equal, but the extraction method dramatically affects purity, potency, and safety. I wish someone had told me early on that CO2-extracted products consistently test cleaner than cheaper solvent-extracted alternatives.

The biggest misconception I encounter is that "natural" always means better. While hemp is natural, creating safe, consistent CBD oil requires sophisticated processing. **Don't be put off by terms like "winterization" or "distillation"** – these steps remove harmful compounds like pesticides and heavy metals. When I started, I thought simpler was better, but proper refinement is what separates premium CBD from questionable products.

---

## Verwandte Studien

Research related to this topic:

- [Differential activation of G protein‐mediated signaling by synthetic cannabinoid... (2020)](/research/study/differential-activation-of-g-proteinmediated-signaling-by-sy-2020-a1f37e) - Human Trial
- [Cannabinoids in the Treatment of [Epilepsy](/conditions/epilepsy): Hard Evidence at Last? (2017)](/research/study/cannabinoids-in-the-treatment-of-epilepsy-hard-evidence-at-l-2017-47a1f3) - Human Trial
- [A Retrospective Analysis of Cannabidiol (CBD) Use in a Concussion Cohort (P7-1.0... (2023)](/research/study/a-retrospective-analysis-of-cannabidiol-cbd-use-in-a-concuss-2023-c36c6c) - Human Trial
- [In situ forming PLA and PLGA implants for the parenteral administration of Canna... (2024)](/research/study/in-situ-forming-pla-and-plga-implants-for-the-parenteral-adm-2024-b7e2f4) - Human Trial
- [Author response: Cannabidiol interactions with voltage-gated sodium channels (2020)](/research/study/author-response-cannabidiol-interactions-with-voltage-gated-2020-ca2c3e) - Human Trial

[Browse all CBD research →](/research)

## Häufig gestellte Fragen

### Is CBD synthetic or natural?

Commercial CBD is extracted from natural hemp plants—it's plant-derived. Synthetic cannabinoids exist but are different substances. Always look for products from natural hemp extraction.

### Why does extraction method matter?

Extraction affects purity, safety, and compound preservation. CO2 extraction leaves no solvent residues and preserves terpenes well. Lower-quality methods may leave residues or destroy beneficial compounds.

### Does CO2 extraction mean higher quality?

Generally, yes. CO2 extraction is considered the gold standard because it's clean, precise, and preserves the full spectrum of compounds. However, ethanol extraction can also produce quality products when done properly.

### What's the difference between crude extract and distillate?

Crude extract is the first result of extraction—contains CBD plus plant material, waxes, and chlorophyll. Distillate is further refined—removing impurities for a cleaner, more concentrated product (70-90% CBD).

### Can I make CBD oil at home?

Technically yes, using olive oil extraction. However, home extraction produces low-potency, imprecise products that spoil quickly. Commercial products offer consistent quality, verified contents, and proper storage stability.

### How do companies control THC levels?

Through genetics (low-THC hemp varieties), testing during cultivation, and post-extraction testing. For [broad spectrum](/glossary/broad-spectrum), additional processing removes THC. All products should be third-party tested to verify THC compliance.

---

*Disclaimer: This article is for informational purposes only. CBD production requires proper licensing, equipment, and compliance with regulations. This is not a guide for manufacturing CBD.*

title: Die Geschichte von CBD und Cannabis: Von der antiken Medizin zur modernen Wissenschaft
excerpt: Entdecken Sie, wie CBD von einer antiken Medizin zu einer verbotenen Substanz und zurück zur Mainstream-Akzeptanz wurde. Diese Geschichte behandelt wichtige Entdeckungen, Prohibition und die moderne Renaissance.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ Jahre in der CBD-Branche Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

Cannabis has been used medicinally for over 5,000 years. CBD was first isolated in 1940, but research stalled due to prohibition. The 2018 Farm Bill (US) and similar legislation globally sparked a renaissance, making CBD one of the most rapidly researched natural compounds today.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ Ancient origins: Cannabis use documented since 2700 BCE in China
  • ✓ CBD isolated 1940: American chemist Roger Adams first extracted CBD
  • ✓ [ECS](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) discovery 1988-1992: Changed our understanding of how cannabinoids work
  • ✓ Prohibition era: Decades of restricted research from 1937 onwards
  • ✓ Modern revival: 2018+ legislation sparked global CBD market growth
  • ✓ First approval: Epidiolex became first approved by regulatory agencies CBD medication in 2018
--- ## Forschungsübersicht | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Studies reviewed | 100 | | Human clinical trials | 98 | | Systematic reviews | 1 | | Preclinical studies | 1 | | Total participants | 163+ | | Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate | *Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)* ## Ancient Origins: Cannabis as Medicine Cannabis is one of the oldest cultivated plants, with humans using it for fibres, food, and medicine for millennia. ### The Earliest Evidence **China (2700 BCE)** The earliest documented medical use of cannabis appears in ancient Chinese texts. Emperor Shen Nung, the "Father of Chinese Medicine," reportedly recommended cannabis tea for various ailments including gout, rheumatism, malaria, and poor memory. The Chinese term for cannabis, "ma," appears in the *Pen Ts'ao Ching*, one of the world's oldest pharmacopoeias. **India (1500-2000 BCE)** In the Atharvaveda, one of four sacred Hindu texts, cannabis is listed among the "five sacred plants." Indian Ayurvedic medicine used cannabis for centuries, calling it "bhang" when consumed orally. **Egypt (1550 BCE)** The Ebers Papyrus, an Egyptian medical text, references cannabis for treating [inflammation](/conditions/inflammation) and [glaucoma](/conditions/glaucoma). ### Cannabis Spreads Globally | Period | Region | Usage | |--------|--------|-------| | 1000 BCE | Middle East | Hashish production, ritual use | | 200 BCE | Greece | Medical texts describe therapeutic use | | 500-1000 CE | Europe | Fiber crops, folk medicine | | 1200 CE | Islamic world | Advanced cannabis medicine documented | | 1500s | Americas | Spanish colonists introduce hemp | ## Key Numbers: CBD and Cannabis History Timeline | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Earliest documented medical use | 2700 BCE | | Year CBD was first isolated | 1940 | | Years cannabis was in US Pharmacopeia | 1850-1942 (92 years) | | Endocannabinoid system discovery period | 1988-1992 | | First FDA-approved CBD medication | 2018 (Epidiolex) | These milestones span nearly 5,000 years of cannabis history, from ancient Chinese medicine to modern pharmaceutical approval. ## 19th Century: Western Medicine Embraces Cannabis Cannabis entered mainstream Western medicine in the 1800s, largely through the work of an Irish physician in India. ### William O'Shaughnessy's Impact In the 1830s-40s, Dr. William Brooke O'Shaughnessy studied cannabis extensively while working for the British East India Company. His research on cannabis for treating tetanus, rabies, cholera, and seizures introduced the plant to European medical practice. **Key findings:** - Documented anticonvulsant properties - Observed analgesic (pain-relieving) effects - Noted [appetite](/conditions/appetite) stimulation - Published influential papers in British medical journals ### Patent Medicines and Tinctures By the late 1800s, cannabis preparations were widely available: **Common uses:** - [Pain](/conditions/pain) relief - [Sleep](/conditions/sleep) aids - Nervous conditions - [Menstrual cramps](/conditions/menstrual-cramps) - Digestive complaints **Notable products:** - Tilden's Extract of Cannabis Indica - Eli Lilly cannabis tinctures - Parke-Davis cannabis preparations - Squibb cannabis medications By 1900, cannabis-based medicines were sold in pharmacies throughout Europe and America. The US Pharmacopeia officially listed cannabis from 1850 to 1942. ## The Prohibition Era Begins The early 20th century brought dramatic changes to cannabis's legal status. ### Factors Leading to Prohibition **Racial and Political Motivations** Anti-cannabis campaigns in the US were heavily influenced by: - Anti-immigrant sentiment targeting Mexican immigrants - Association of cannabis with minority communities - "Reefer Madness" propaganda (1936) - Political interests in regulating competition with industrial interests **Regulatory Actions** | Year | Event | |------|-------| | 1906 | Pure Food and Drug Act (US) requires cannabis labelling | | 1914 | Harrison Narcotics Tax Act sets precedent | | 1925 | Geneva International Convention restricts cannabis | | 1930 | Federal Bureau of Narcotics established | | 1937 | **Marihuana Tax Act** effectively prohibits cannabis | | 1961 | UN Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs | | 1970 | Controlled Substances Act (US) classifies as Schedule I | ### The Impact on Research Prohibition severely limited scientific investigation: - Researchers needed special licences - Funding dried up - Cannabis lumped with dangerous drugs - Medical knowledge from the 1800s largely forgotten - Decades of potential research lost ## Scientific Breakthroughs (1940-1992) Despite prohibition, dedicated scientists made crucial discoveries. ### 1940: CBD Is First Isolated American chemist **Roger Adams** at the University of Illinois isolated [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) from cannabis for the first time. He also identified the structure of [CBN](/glossary/cannabinol) (cannabinol). **What Adams discovered:** - CBD's basic chemical structure - That CBD is non-intoxicating - The presence of multiple cannabinoids in cannabis However, Adams was unable to fully determine CBD's three-dimensional structure, and prohibition limited further research. ### 1963-1964: Raphael Mechoulam's Transformative Work Israeli scientist **Dr. Raphael Mechoulam**, often called the "Father of Cannabis Research," made breakthroughs that shaped the field: **1963:** Determined the exact chemical structure of CBD **1964:** Isolated and synthesised [THC](/glossary/tetrahydrocannabinol), identifying it as the primary intoxicating compound **Why this mattered:** - Explained why some cannabis effects were intoxicating and others weren't - Enabled researchers to study individual cannabinoids - Provided foundation for all future cannabis science Dr. Mechoulam continued research for 60+ years, publishing over 400 scientific papers before his death in 2023. ### 1988: Discovery of the First Cannabinoid Receptor At St. Louis University, **Allyn Howlett** and **William Devane** discovered the [CB1 receptor](/glossary/cb1-receptor)—a protein structure in the brain that THC binds to. **Implications:** - Proved cannabinoids work through specific receptors - Suggested the body has its own cannabinoid system - Opened entirely new fields of research ### 1992: The Endocannabinoid System Revealed **Raphael Mechoulam** and **William Devane** discovered [anandamide](/glossary/anandamide)—an endocannabinoid produced naturally by the human body. **This was revolutionary because:** - It proved humans make their own cannabinoid-like chemicals - It explained why cannabinoid receptors exist - It revealed the [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) (ECS) as a major regulatory network **1993:** The [CB2 receptor](/glossary/cb2-receptor) was discovered, primarily in immune tissue. **1995:** A second endocannabinoid, [2-AG](/glossary/2-ag), was identified. ## The CBD Renaissance (1990s-2010s) > For more information, see our guide on [Charlotte's Web Story: The Case That Changed CBD History](/articles/charlottes-web-story). Scientific understanding grew, even as legal restrictions remained. ### Growing Research Interest Throughout the 1990s and 2000s, researchers published studies suggesting CBD might have: - Anti-inflammatory properties - Neuroprotective potential - Anxiolytic (anti-anxiety) effects - Anticonvulsant activity **Key research milestones:** | Year | Discovery | |------|-----------| | 1998 | GW Pharmaceuticals begins developing cannabis-based medicines | | 2003 | US government patents cannabinoids as neuroprotectants (Patent 6,630,507) | | 2005 | Sativex (CBD/THC) approved in Canada for MS symptoms | | 2007 | Studies show CBD's anti-inflammatory mechanisms | | 2009 | Research demonstrates CBD's effect on [serotonin](/conditions/serotonin) receptors | ### Charlotte's Story: CBD Enters Public Consciousness In 2013, the story of **Charlotte Figi** brought CBD to international attention. **The case:** - Charlotte had Dravet syndrome, a severe form of [epilepsy](/conditions/epilepsy) - She experienced hundreds of seizures weekly - Conventional treatments had failed - Her [parents](/conditions/parents) tried a high-CBD, low-THC cannabis extract - Her seizures dropped from 300+ per week to 2-3 per month CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta documentary "Weed" aired Charlotte's story to millions, dramatically shifting public perception of medical cannabis and CBD specifically. A CBD-rich cannabis strain was later named "Charlotte's Web" in her honour. ## Legal Shifts and Market Expansion (2014-Present) The mid-2010s brought rapid legal and commercial changes. ### United States **2014:** Farm Bill allows hemp pilot programmes **2018:** The **Agricultural Improvement Act** (Farm Bill) removes [hemp](/glossary/hemp) (cannabis with <0.3% THC) from the Controlled Substances Act, effectively legalising hemp-derived CBD federally. **2018:** **Epidiolex** (pharmaceutical CBD) becomes the first cannabis-derived medication approved by regulatory agencies, for treating Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and Dravet syndrome. **Impact:** - Massive market expansion - Thousands of CBD brands launched - Agricultural hemp cultivation returned - Research restrictions eased ### Europe **EU [Novel Food Regulation](/glossary/novel-food):** CBD classified as a "[novel food](/glossary/novel-food)," requiring authorisation for ingestible products. **Key developments:** | Year | Country | Development | |------|---------|-------------| | 2019 | UK | FSA acknowledges CBD as novel food | | 2020 | EU | Court rules CBD not a narcotic | | 2022 | Germany | Coalition agreement to legalise cannabis | | 2024 | Germany | Adult-use cannabis legalised | **European countries with established CBD markets:** - United Kingdom - Switzerland (allows up to 1% THC) - Germany - Netherlands - Czech Republic - Spain ### Global Picture | Region | Status (2026) | |--------|---------------| | **North America** | US, Canada: Hemp CBD legal; Mexico: liberalising | | **Europe** | Most countries: CBD legal with THC limits | | **Asia** | Generally restrictive; Thailand exception | | **Australia** | Low-dose CBD OTC approved (2021) | | **South America** | Varies; Brazil, Colombia more permissive | | **Africa** | Emerging; South Africa, Lesotho producing | ## Scientific Research Today The 2018+ legal shifts unlocked unprecedented research. ### Current Research Areas **[Neurological](/conditions/neurological) conditions:** - Epilepsy (most established) - [Parkinson's](/conditions/parkinsons) disease - [Multiple sclerosis](/conditions/ms) - [Alzheimer's](/conditions/alzheimers) research **Mental health:** - [Anxiety](/conditions/anxiety) disorders - [PTSD](/conditions/ptsd) - [Depression](/conditions/depression) - Sleep disorders **Pain and inflammation:** - [Chronic pain](/conditions/chronic_pain) - [Arthritis](/conditions/arthritis) - Inflammatory bowel disease - [Fibromyalgia](/conditions/fibromyalgia) **Other areas:** - [Addiction](/conditions/addiction) treatment - Skin conditions - Metabolic disorders - Cardiovascular research ### Research Limitations Despite progress, challenges remain: **Regulatory hurdles:** - Some countries still restrict research - Lengthy approval processes - Complex regulations **Scientific challenges:** - Standardisation of products - Optimal dosing unclear - Long-term studies needed - Individual variation in response ## Timeline Summary | Period | Key Events | |--------|------------| | **Ancient (2700 BCE+)** | Cannabis used medicinally across civilisations | | **1800s** | Western medicine embraces cannabis tinctures | | **1930s-1970s** | Prohibition spreads globally | | **1940** | Roger Adams isolates CBD | | **1963-1964** | Mechoulam determines CBD/THC structure | | **1988-1995** | ECS discovered (receptors, anandamide, 2-AG) | | **2013** | Charlotte Figi story sparks CBD interest | | **2018** | Farm Bill (US); Epidiolex approved | | **2020s** | Global market expansion; research acceleration | ## The Future of CBD Several trends are shaping CBD's trajectory: ### Research Directions - More clinical trials (particularly large-scale) - Mechanism of action studies - Personalised dosing approaches - Minor cannabinoid research (CBG, CBN, CBC) - Synergistic effects ([entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect)) ### Regulatory Evolution - Novel food approvals progressing - Quality standards developing - Medical cannabis expansion - Potential pharmaceutical applications beyond epilepsy ### Market Maturation - Consolidation of brands - Quality differentiation - Consumer education improving - Product innovation continuing --- ## Verwandte Studien Research related to this topic: - [Medicinal Use of Cannabis: History and Current Status (2001)](/research/study/medicinal-use-of-cannabis-history-and-current-status-2001-b13c1f) - Human Trial - [Efficacy of Add-on Cannabidiol (CBD) Treatment in Patients with Tuberous Scleros... (2021)](/research/study/efficacy-of-add-on-cannabidiol-cbd-treatment-in-patients-wit-2021-742d83) - Human Trial - [History of Cannabis and Its Preparations in Saga, Science, and Sobriquet (2007)](/research/study/history-of-cannabis-and-its-preparations-in-saga-science-and-2007-963067) - Human Trial - [Sexually-dimorphic alterations in cannabinoid receptor density depend upon prena... (2016)](/research/study/sexually-dimorphic-alterations-in-cannabinoid-receptor-densi-2016-d43ceb) - Human Trial - [A drug discovery case history of ‘delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol, cannabidiol’ (2011)](/research/study/a-drug-discovery-case-history-of-delta-9-tetrahydrocannabino-2011-87f606) - Human Trial [Browse all CBD research →](/research) ## Meine Meinung After over a decade in this industry, I'm constantly amazed by how cannabis went from ancient medicine to modern taboo and back to legitimate wellness again. The most common question I get is "Why did it take so long for CBD to become mainstream?" The answer lies in that lost century of research between prohibition and legalization. What fascinates me most is reviewing studies from the 1940s-60s that were essentially buried until recently. Dr. Raphael Mechoulam's groundbreaking work in the 1960s laid foundations we're still building on today. I've tested products that would have been unimaginable even five years ago – nano-emulsions, water-soluble formulations, targeted delivery systems. The real game-changer wasn't just the 2018 Farm Bill, but the flood of institutional research funding that followed. Universities that couldn't touch cannabis for decades are now leading cutting-edge studies. We're witnessing the fastest acceleration of cannabinoid research in human history. ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### When was CBD discovered? CBD was first isolated in 1940 by American chemist Roger Adams at the University of Illinois. However, its precise chemical structure wasn't determined until 1963 when Israeli scientist Raphael Mechoulam completed this work. The compound existed and was used within cannabis for thousands of years before scientists identified it. ### Who discovered the endocannabinoid system? The endocannabinoid system was discovered through work by multiple scientists. Allyn Howlett and William Devane discovered the [CB1](/glossary/cb1-receptor) receptor in 1988. Raphael Mechoulam and William Devane then discovered anandamide (the first known endocannabinoid) in 1992. These discoveries revealed that humans have an entire biological system devoted to cannabinoid-like compounds. ### Why was cannabis prohibition introduced? Cannabis prohibition in the early 20th century resulted from multiple factors: anti-immigrant sentiment (particularly targeting Mexican and African American communities), competition with industrial interests, misleading propaganda campaigns, and political motivations. The 1937 Marihuana Tax Act effectively criminalised cannabis in the US, and international conventions spread prohibition globally. ### When did CBD become legal? CBD's legal status varies by country. In the US, hemp-derived CBD became federally legal with the 2018 Farm Bill. In Europe, the 2020 EU Court ruling confirmed CBD isn't a narcotic, though countries have different regulations. Legality depends on THC content, product type, and local laws—always check current regulations in your jurisdiction. ### What was the first CBD medication approved? Epidiolex (known as Epidyolex in Europe) became the first CBD medication approved by regulatory agencies in June 2018. It's a pharmaceutical-grade CBD solution approved for treating seizures associated with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, Dravet syndrome, and tuberous sclerosis complex. ### Why is Raphael Mechoulam important to CBD history? Raphael Mechoulam (1930-2023) is considered the "Father of Cannabis Research." He determined the exact structure of CBD (1963), isolated and synthesised THC (1964), discovered anandamide (1992), and published over 400 scientific papers on cannabinoids. His work provided the scientific foundation for modern cannabis medicine and CBD research. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [Introduction to CBD](/articles/introduction-to-cbd) - [The Endocannabinoid System Explained](/articles/endocannabinoid-system) - [What is CBD?](/articles/what-is-cbd) - [How CBD Works in the Body](/articles/how-cbd-works) - [What Are Cannabinoids?](/articles/what-are-cannabinoids) --- ## Sources 1. Russo E. (2007). "History of Cannabis and Its Preparations in Saga, Science, and Sobriquet." *Chemistry & Biodiversity*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17712811/) 2. Zuardi AW. (2006). "A historical overview of chemical research on cannabinoids." *Chemistry and Physics of Lipids*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11106785/) 4. Pertwee RG. (2006). title: Warum Menschen CBD verwenden: Die häufigsten Gründe und Anwendungsfälle
excerpt: Entdecken Sie, warum Millionen täglich CBD verwenden. Erfahren Sie die wichtigsten Gründe—Angst, Schlaf, Schmerzen, Wellness—und was Menschen zu dieser natürlichen Verbindung zieht.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ Jahre in der CBD-Branche
Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026

---

---

## Forschungsübersicht

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 100 |
| Human clinical trials | 98 |
| Systematic reviews | 1 |
| Preclinical studies | 1 |
| Total participants | 163+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Schnelle Antwort

**People use [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) primarily for [stress](/conditions/stress) relief, better [sleep](/conditions/sleep), [pain](/conditions/pain) management, and general wellness.** Survey data shows [anxiety](/conditions/anxiety) and stress reduction are the top reasons, followed by sleep support and [chronic pain](/conditions/chronic_pain). CBD appeals to those seeking natural alternatives to pharmaceuticals. While research is ongoing, millions use CBD daily as part of their wellness routine.

---

## Key Numbers: CBD Usage Patterns

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Top reason for use | 47-62% use for anxiety/stress |
| Sleep support users | 40-52% of CBD users |
| Chronic pain management | 35-48% of users |
| Primary age demographic | 25-54 years most common |
| General wellness users | 25-37% use preventively |

These statistics reflect consistent patterns across multiple CBD user surveys, with many users citing multiple reasons for their CBD use.

## Wichtigste Erkenntnisse

- **Stress and anxiety relief** are the #1 reason people use CBD
- **Sleep support** is the second most common use
- **Pain management** (chronic, inflammatory, exercise-related) is widely reported
- **General wellness** and preventive use are growing motivations
- People often try CBD when **conventional options haven't worked** well
- CBD's **non-intoxicating nature** is a key appeal

---

## What Survey Data Shows

Multiple surveys reveal consistent patterns in why people choose CBD.

### Top Reasons for CBD Use (Survey Data)

| Reason | % of Users |
|--------|------------|
| **Anxiety/stress** | 47-62% |
| **Sleep issues** | 40-52% |
| **Chronic pain** | 35-48% |
| **General wellness** | 25-37% |
| **[Inflammation](/conditions/inflammation)** | 20-30% |
| **Relaxation** | 18-28% |
| **[Depression](/conditions/depression)** | 15-25% |
| **Skin conditions** | 10-15% |

*Note: Percentages vary by survey; users often cite multiple reasons.*

### Who Uses CBD?

| Demographic | Finding |
|-------------|---------|
| **Age** | Most common: 25-54 years |
| **Gender** | Roughly equal, slight female majority |
| **Previous cannabis use** | Many users have never used [THC](/glossary/thc) products |
| **Condition status** | Both diagnosed conditions and general wellness |

---

## Primary Use Cases

### 1. Stress and Anxiety

The most cited reason for CBD use.

| Why People Try It | What Users Report |
|-------------------|-------------------|
| Daily stress relief | Feeling calmer |
| [Social anxiety](/conditions/social-anxiety) | Reduced nervousness |
| Work-related tension | Better able to cope |
| General anxiousness | Quieter mind |

**How CBD may help:** CBD interacts with [5-HT1A [serotonin](/conditions/serotonin) receptors](/glossary/serotonin-receptors-5ht1a), which regulate [mood](/conditions/mood) and anxiety.

### 2. Sleep Support

| Sleep Issue | How CBD Is Used |
|-------------|-----------------|
| Difficulty falling asleep | Evening dose before bed |
| Waking during night | Sustained-release or longer-acting forms |
| Racing thoughts at bedtime | Combined with relaxation routine |
| Sleep quality | Regular daily use |

**Why it may help:** CBD may address underlying anxiety or discomfort that disrupts sleep, rather than causing sedation directly.

### 3. Pain Management

| Pain Type | Common Use Pattern |
|-----------|-------------------|
| Chronic pain | Daily oral dosing |
| [Arthritis](/conditions/arthritis)/joint pain | Oral + topical combination |
| [Back pain](/conditions/back-pain) | Oral CBD, topicals on area |
| Exercise soreness | Post-[workout recovery](/conditions/workout-recovery) |
| [Headaches](/conditions/headaches)/[migraines](/conditions/migraines) | Preventive and acute use |

**Mechanisms:** CBD interacts with [TRPV1 receptors](/glossary/trpv1-receptor) (pain perception) and has anti-inflammatory properties.

### 4. General Wellness

| Wellness Goal | User Approach |
|---------------|---------------|
| Daily balance | Low-dose routine |
| [ECS support](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) | Regular supplementation |
| Preventive care | Consistent use |
| Mood stability | Daily maintenance |

**Growing trend:** Many users take CBD without a specific condition—similar to taking vitamins.

---

## Why People Choose CBD Specifically

### Appeal Factors

| Factor | Why It Matters |
|--------|----------------|
| **Non-intoxicating** | No high, can work/drive normally |
| **Natural origin** | Plant-derived, not synthetic |
| **Well-tolerated** | Fewer side effects than many medications |
| **Legal and accessible** | Available without prescription |
| **Flexible use** | Multiple formats, easy to incorporate |
| **Growing research** | Increasing scientific support |

### Common Reasons for Trying CBD


> For more information, see our guide on [Why CBD Works Differently for Different People](/articles/why-cbd-works-differently).
| Trigger | Context |
|---------|---------|
| **Conventional treatments inadequate** | Side effects or insufficient relief |
| **Seeking natural alternatives** | Preference for plant-based options |
| **Recommendation from others** | Friends, family, online communities |
| **Curiosity from media coverage** | Growing awareness |
| **Desire to reduce pharmaceuticals** | Looking for alternatives |

---

## CBD for Specific Populations

### Athletes and Fitness

| Use Case | Why Athletes Use CBD |
|----------|---------------------|
| **Post-workout recovery** | May reduce inflammation |
| **Sleep quality** | Recovery happens during sleep |
| **Competition anxiety** | WADA removed CBD from banned list |
| **Pain management** | Alternative to NSAIDs |

### [Seniors](/conditions/seniors)

| Use Case | Why Older Adults Use CBD |
|----------|-------------------------|
| **Chronic pain** | Arthritis, joint issues common |
| **Sleep issues** | Sleep quality decreases with age |
| **Reduced medications** | Seek alternatives with fewer interactions |
| **Anxiety** | Health-related worries |

*Note: Drug interactions are more common in seniors—always consult a healthcare provider.*

### Working Professionals

| Use Case | Why Professionals Use CBD |
|----------|--------------------------|
| **Stress management** | Work-related pressure |
| **[Focus](/conditions/focus)** | Reduced anxiety may improve concentration |
| **Better sleep** | Performance depends on rest |
| **Non-impairing** | Can use without affecting work |

---

## What Research Supports

### Areas with Research Support

| Use | Evidence Level |
|-----|----------------|
| **Certain seizure disorders** | Strong (approved by regulatory agencies Epidiolex) |
| **Anxiety** | Moderate (clinical trials ongoing) |
| **Chronic pain** | Moderate (more research needed) |
| **Inflammation** | Preclinical support |
| **Sleep** | Limited direct evidence |

### Important Caveats

| Consideration | Reality |
|---------------|---------|
| **Not a cure** | CBD doesn't cure any condition |
| **Individual variation** | Results vary significantly |
| **Research ongoing** | Many questions unanswered |
| **Product quality matters** | Low-quality products may not work |

---

## What CBD Is NOT Used For

### Misconceptions

| Misconception | Reality |
|---------------|---------|
| **Getting high** | CBD is non-intoxicating |
| **Replacing all medication** | Should complement, not replace medical care |
| **Instant cure** | Benefits often build over time |
| **One-size-fits-all** | Optimal dose varies by person |

---

## How to Start Using CBD

### For New Users

| Step | Guidance |
|------|----------|
| **1. Identify your goal** | What do you want to address? |
| **2. Choose product type** | Oil, capsule, gummy, etc. |
| **3. Select spectrum** | [Full](/glossary/full-spectrum), [broad](/glossary/broad-spectrum), or [isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) |
| **4. Start low** | 10-20mg per day |
| **5. Be patient** | Give it 2-4 weeks |
| **6. Adjust gradually** | Increase dose if needed |

### Choosing by Use Case

| Goal | Product Suggestion |
|------|-------------------|
| **General wellness** | Daily CBD oil |
| **Sleep** | Higher-dose evening gummy or oil |
| **Pain (local)** | Topical + oral combination |
| **Stress** | [Sublingual](/glossary/sublingual) oil for faster effect |

---

## Verwandte Artikel

- [What Does CBD Feel Like?](/articles/what-does-cbd-feel-like) - Understanding effects
- [Does CBD Get You High?](/articles/does-cbd-get-you-high) - Intoxication facts
- [How CBD Works](/articles/how-cbd-works) - The science explained
- [Full Spectrum vs Broad Spectrum vs Isolate](/articles/spectrum-comparison) - Choosing your type

---


## Meine Meinung

After 12+ years in this industry, I've seen firsthand why this question matters so much to [beginners](/conditions/beginners). When I started, CBD felt like this mysterious compound with wild claims everywhere. What I wish I'd known then is that most people aren't using CBD as a miracle cure – they're using it as a practical wellness tool, like taking vitamins or going for walks.

The biggest misconception I encounter is that CBD should work the same for everyone. In reality, your reasons for trying CBD will likely evolve. You might start for sleep but discover it helps with daily stress. Or begin with post-workout recovery and find it supports your overall mood. Understanding why others use CBD helps you set realistic expectations for your own journey.

---

## Verwandte Studien

Research related to this topic:

- [Values and preferences towards medical cannabis among people living with chronic... (2021)](/research/study/values-and-preferences-towards-medical-cannabis-among-people-2021-8b9181) - Human Trial
- [Cannabis Exposure is Associated With a Lower Likelihood of Neurocognitive Impair... (2019)](/research/study/cannabis-exposure-is-associated-with-a-lower-likelihood-of-n-2019-9933e2) - Human Trial
- [Effects of the Cannabinoid-1 Receptor Antagonist Rimonabant on Psychiatric Sympt... (2010)](/research/study/effects-of-the-cannabinoid-1-receptor-antagonist-rimonabant-2010-3e4ae3) - Human Trial
- [Antiseizure medication prescribing in people with Dravet syndrome: An analysis o... (2025)](/research/study/antiseizure-medication-prescribing-in-people-with-dravet-syn-2025-72500e) - Human Trial
- [Cannabis Consumption in People Living with HIV: Reasons for Use, Secondary Effec... (2019)](/research/study/cannabis-consumption-in-people-living-with-hiv-reasons-for-u-2019-49ccda) - Human Trial

[Browse all CBD research →](/research)

## Häufig gestellte Fragen

### What is the most common reason people use CBD?

Stress and anxiety relief. Surveys consistently show 47-62% of CBD users cite anxiety as a primary reason. Sleep support and pain management follow closely behind.

### Can CBD replace my medication?

CBD should not replace prescribed medication without consulting your doctor. It may complement existing treatments, but many conditions require medical management. Always discuss CBD use with a healthcare provider.

### How quickly will CBD work for me?

Depends on use case and delivery method. Acute effects (calm, relaxation) may appear within 15-60 minutes. Chronic conditions often require 2-4 weeks of consistent use before noticing changes.

### Do people use CBD without having a medical condition?

Yes, increasingly so. Many people use CBD for general wellness—similar to supplements or vitamins—to support their [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) without targeting a specific issue.

### Is CBD effective for everyone?

No. Individual responses vary significantly due to genetics, [endocannabinoid tone](/glossary/endocannabinoid-tone), metabolism, and other factors. Some people experience significant benefits; others notice little effect. Product quality also matters.

### Why are so many people trying CBD now?

Several factors: increasing research and media coverage, legal clarity in many regions, growing distrust of pharmaceuticals, desire for natural alternatives, and word-of-mouth from satisfied users.

---

*Medizinischer Haftungsausschluss: Dieser Artikel dient nur zu Informationszwecken und stellt keine medizinische Beratung dar. CBD is not approved to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. Konsultieren Sie einen Arzt, bevor Sie CBD verwenden, especially if you have a medical condition or take medications.*
