title: CBD-Kaufratgeber: Alles, was Sie vor dem Kauf wissen müssen
excerpt: Navigieren Sie selbstbewusst durch den CBD-Markt. Dieser umfassende Kaufratgeber behandelt alles vom Lesen von Laborberichten bis zur Bewertung von Marken.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

Buy CBD from brands that provide third-party lab reports (COAs), clearly state CBD content in mg, use quality hemp sources, and have transparent business practices. Start with reputable, established brands rather than the cheapest option. Quality costs more but delivers better value.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ Demand lab reports: Third-party COAs are non-negotiable
  • ✓ Check CBD content: Always look for mg amounts, not just percentages
  • ✓ Know your spectrum: Full-spectrum, broad-spectrum, or [isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) each has pros/cons
  • ✓ Compare cost per mg: Price per bottle is misleading; calculate mg value
  • ✓ Research the brand: Longevity, reviews, and transparency matter
  • ✓ Avoid red flags: Health claims, no lab reports, unclear labelling
--- ## Forschungsübersicht | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Studies reviewed | 100 | | Human clinical trials | 98 | | Systematic reviews | 1 | | Preclinical studies | 1 | | Total participants | 163+ | | Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate | *Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)* ## Why Quality Matters The CBD market grew rapidly without strict oversight, leading to significant quality variation. Studies have found: - Some products contain far less CBD than claimed - Some products contain more [THC](/glossary/thc) than legal limits - Contaminants (pesticides, heavy metals, solvents) appear in some products - Labelling accuracy varies widely between brands **Buying smart protects your:** - Health (avoiding contaminants) - Money (getting what you pay for) - Legal safety (ensuring THC compliance) - Results (accurate dosing for consistent effects) ## Key Numbers: CBD Product Quality & Safety | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Legal THC limit (EU) | <0.2% | | Legal THC limit (US) | <0.3% | | Acceptable CBD content variance | ±10% from label claim | | Standard bottle size for calculations | 30mL | | Gold standard lab accreditation | ISO 17025 | These numbers represent critical thresholds for ensuring CBD product legality, accuracy, and safety when evaluating lab reports and certificates of analysis. ## Understanding Lab Reports (COAs) A [Certificate of Analysis](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) (COA) is your most important tool when evaluating CBD products. ### What Is a COA? A [COA](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) is a document from an independent laboratory that tests CBD products for content and safety. It should be available for every batch produced. ### Where to Find COAs Quality brands make COAs accessible: - QR code on product packaging - Product page on company website - "Lab Reports" or "Testing" section of website - Upon request via customer service **Red flag:** If you can't easily find lab reports, don't buy from that company. ### What to Look for in a COA #### 1. Cannabinoid Profile This section tells you exactly what cannabinoids are in the product. | What to Check | Why It Matters | |---------------|----------------| | **CBD content** | Should match label claims (±10% is acceptable) | | **THC content** | Must be under legal limit (<0.2% in EU, <0.3% in US) | | **Other cannabinoids** | Confirms spectrum type (full, broad, isolate) | | **CBDA/THCA** | Raw forms; should be minimal in processed products | **Example calculation:** If a 30mL bottle claims 1000mg CBD and the COA shows 32mg/mL, multiply: 32 × 30 = 960mg. That's within acceptable range of the 1000mg claim. #### 2. Contaminant Testing Look for these safety panels: | Test Panel | What It Detects | Pass/Fail | |------------|-----------------|-----------| | **Pesticides** | Chemical residues from cultivation | Should be "ND" (not detected) | | **Heavy metals** | Lead, arsenic, mercury, cadmium | Below safe limits | | **Residual solvents** | Leftover extraction chemicals | Below safe limits | | **Microbial** | Bacteria, mould, yeast | Below safe limits | | **Mycotoxins** | Fungal toxins | Should be "ND" | #### 3. Verification Details Check these elements to ensure legitimacy: - **Lab name and accreditation** (ISO 17025 is the gold standard) - **Date of testing** (should be recent, within the year) - **Batch/lot number** (should match your product) - **Sample ID** (links report to specific product) ### How to Verify a COA Is Legitimate 1. Check the lab name is real (search online) 2. Verify lab accreditation 3. Match batch numbers on COA to product label 4. Ensure test date is reasonable 5. Look for proper lab formatting (not homemade-looking) ## Choosing the Right Spectrum Type Understanding spectrum types helps you choose the right product for your needs. ### Full-Spectrum CBD [Full-spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) contains CBD plus other cannabinoids, [terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile), and plant compounds, including trace THC (<0.2% EU / <0.3% US). **Pros:** - [Entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect) may enhance benefits - Natural plant profile preserved - Most research uses full-spectrum **Cons:** - Contains trace THC (drug test consideration) - Stronger hemp taste - Some people sensitive to other cannabinoids **Best for:** - Those wanting complete plant benefits - No [drug testing](/conditions/drug-testing) concerns - Experienced CBD users ### Broad-Spectrum CBD [Broad-spectrum](/glossary/broad-spectrum) contains CBD and other cannabinoids/terpenes but with THC removed. **Pros:** - Entourage effect (partial) - Zero/near-zero THC - Lower drug test risk **Cons:** - Processing removes some compounds - May be slightly less effective than full-spectrum - Quality varies by brand **Best for:** - Drug-tested individuals - THC-sensitive people - Those wanting more than isolate ### CBD Isolate [CBD isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) is pure CBD (99%+) with no other cannabinoids or terpenes. **Pros:** - Zero THC guaranteed - No hemp taste - Precise dosing - Good for DIY products **Cons:** - No entourage effect - May require higher doses - Missing complementary compounds **Best for:** - Guaranteed THC-free needs - Taste-sensitive users - Adding to foods/recipes ### Spectrum Comparison Summary | Factor | Full-Spectrum | Broad-Spectrum | Isolate | |--------|---------------|----------------|---------| | **Entourage effect** | Full | Partial | None | | **THC content** | Trace (<0.2%) | None/minimal | None | | **Drug test risk** | Possible | Very low | None | | **Taste** | Hemp-like | Milder | Neutral | | **Price** | Mid-High | Mid-High | Low-Mid | ## Product Type Selection Different formats suit different needs. Choose based on your goals and preferences. ### CBD Oils / Tinctures The most versatile option for most users. | Aspect | Details | |--------|---------| | **Best for** | Flexibility, fast-acting, daily use | | **Onset** | 15-30 minutes (sublingual) | | **Duration** | 4-6 hours | | **[Bioavailability](/glossary/bioavailability)** | 13-35% | | **Dosing** | Highly adjustable | **What to look for:** - Clear mg per bottle stated - Quality carrier oil (MCT, hemp seed, olive) - Dropper for measurement - Natural or clearly labelled flavourings ### CBD Capsules / Softgels Convenient and consistent. | Aspect | Details | |--------|---------| | **Best for** | Convenience, consistency, no taste | | **Onset** | 30-90 minutes | | **Duration** | 6-8 hours | | **Bioavailability** | 6-15% | | **Dosing** | Pre-measured, fixed | **What to look for:** - Clear mg per capsule - Quality ingredients in capsule shell - Reputable brand with COAs ### CBD Gummies / Edibles > For more information, see our guide on [CBD Buying Mistakes: 10 Errors to Avoid](/articles/cbd-buying-mistakes). Enjoyable and discreet. > For more information, see our guide on [What to Look For When Buying CBD: Complete Buyer's Guide](/articles/what-to-look-for-buying-cbd). | Aspect | Details | |--------|---------| | **Best for** | Taste, discretion, enjoyment | | **Onset** | 30-90 minutes | | **Duration** | 6-8 hours | | **Bioavailability** | 6-15% | | **Dosing** | Pre-measured per piece | **What to look for:** - Clear mg per gummy (not just per bottle) - Quality sweeteners and ingredients - Consistency between pieces (COA batch testing) ### CBD Topicals For targeted, localised use. | Aspect | Details | |--------|---------| | **Best for** | Targeted areas, skin concerns | | **Onset** | 15-45 minutes | | **Duration** | 2-4 hours | | **Bioavailability** | Localised | | **Dosing** | Variable | **What to look for:** - CBD mg per container clearly stated - Quality additional ingredients - Appropriate for intended use area ### CBD Vapes Fast-acting but with considerations. | Aspect | Details | |--------|---------| | **Best for** | Rapid effects | | **Onset** | 1-5 minutes | | **Duration** | 2-3 hours | | **Bioavailability** | 30-50% | | **Dosing** | Variable | **What to look for:** - Clean ingredients (avoid harmful additives) - Specific vape COA testing - Reputable vape-specific brand ## Calculating Value: Cost Per mg Don't compare bottle prices—compare cost per mg of CBD. ### The Formula **Cost per mg = Price ÷ Total mg** ### Example Comparisons | Product | Price | Total mg | Cost per mg | |---------|-------|----------|-------------| | Brand A 30mL | £40 | 500mg | £0.08/mg | | Brand B 30mL | £60 | 1000mg | £0.06/mg | | Brand C 30mL | £90 | 2000mg | £0.045/mg | | Brand D 30mL | £25 | 250mg | £0.10/mg | In this example, Brand C offers the best value per mg despite being the most expensive bottle. ### Typical Price Ranges (2026) | Quality Tier | Cost per mg | What You Get | |--------------|-------------|--------------| | **Budget** | £0.10-0.15/mg | Basic quality, less testing | | **Mid-range** | £0.05-0.10/mg | Good quality, full testing | | **Premium** | £0.03-0.06/mg | Excellent quality, extensive testing | | **Pharmaceutical** | Varies | Medical-grade, prescription only | **Warning:** Extremely cheap products (under £0.03/mg) often cut corners on quality or contain less CBD than claimed. ## Brand Evaluation Checklist Use these criteria to evaluate any CBD brand. ### Essential Criteria (Must Have) - [ ] **Third-party lab testing** for every product - [ ] **Accessible COAs** (website or QR code) - [ ] **Clear labelling** with mg content - [ ] **Contact information** (customer service) - [ ] **Legal compliance** (THC within limits) ### Important Criteria (Should Have) - [ ] **Hemp source information** (where grown, organic status) - [ ] **Extraction method stated** (CO2 preferred) - [ ] **Company history** (at least 2+ years in business) - [ ] **Multiple product reviews** from verified purchasers - [ ] **Return/refund policy** in place - [ ] **Educational content** on their website ### Bonus Criteria (Nice to Have) - [ ] **Certifications** (organic, GMP, etc.) - [ ] **Scientific advisors** or medical board - [ ] **Detailed ingredient sourcing** - [ ] **Sustainable practices** - [ ] **Industry associations** membership ## Red Flags to Avoid These warning signs suggest a brand should be avoided. ### Definite Red Flags | Red Flag | Why It's Concerning | |----------|---------------------| | **No lab reports** | Can't verify quality or safety | | **Disease claims** | Illegal and indicates lack of compliance | | **"Miracle cure" language** | Dishonest marketing | | **No contact information** | No accountability | | **Only percentage, no mg** | Obscures actual CBD content | | **Unrealistically cheap** | Likely low quality or mislabelled | ### Concerning Signs - Aggressive marketing with exaggerated claims - No company information (who owns/operates it) - Only positive reviews (may be fake) - Website looks unprofessional or incomplete - "Proprietary blend" without CBD mg specified - Uses "hemp oil" without specifying CBD content ### Examples of Misleading Labels | What They Say | What It Might Mean | |---------------|-------------------| | "1000mg hemp extract" | Could be hemp seed oil, not CBD | | "Extra strength" | Meaningless without mg stated | | "Industrial hemp oil" | May contain no CBD | | "Full plant extract" | Vague, unclear CBD content | | "10,000mg per bottle" | Could be total hemp compounds, not CBD | ## Shopping Channels Compared Where you buy affects quality assurance. ### Direct from Brand Websites **Pros:** - Freshest products - Full selection - Direct customer support - Authentic products guaranteed - Often best deals/subscriptions **Cons:** - Shipping costs - Limited comparison shopping ### Specialised CBD Retailers **Pros:** - Curated selection - Brand comparison - Often knowledgeable staff - Quality vetting (ideally) **Cons:** - Markup on prices - Quality vetting varies ### General E-commerce (Amazon, etc.) **Pros:** - Convenient - Reviews available - Fast shipping **Cons:** - Authenticity not guaranteed - Many mislabelled products - CBD regulations often prohibit sales (policy violations) ### Pharmacies/Health Shops **Pros:** - Trusted retail environment - Staff may have knowledge - Products usually vetted **Cons:** - Limited selection - Higher prices - Staff knowledge varies ## Step-by-Step Buying Process Follow this process for your next CBD purchase. ### Step 1: Define Your Needs Answer these questions: - What do I want to use CBD for? - Do I need to avoid THC? - What format would I prefer? - What's my budget? - How often will I use it? ### Step 2: Research Brands For each brand you're considering: 1. Find their COAs and verify quality 2. Check company history and reputation 3. Read multiple reviews (various sources) 4. Verify they meet essential criteria ### Step 3: Compare Products Within your chosen brands: 1. Calculate cost per mg 2. Compare spectrum types 3. Check ingredients 4. Consider bottle size for your usage ### Step 4: Start Small For first purchases: - Buy smaller sizes first - Test before committing to larger orders - Keep notes on your experience ### Step 5: Evaluate and Adjust After using the product: - Did the product meet expectations? - Was the company responsive? - Would you repurchase? - What would you change? ## Special Considerations ### Drug Testing Concerns If you're subject to drug testing: - Choose broad-spectrum or isolate products - Avoid full-spectrum - Verify THC is undetectable on COA - Be aware no product is 100% risk-free ### Medication Interactions If you take medications: - Consult your doctor before buying - Be particularly careful with [blood thinners](/conditions/blood-thinners), heart meds, seizure medications - Start with lower doses - Monitor for changes ### Travelling with CBD If you'll travel with CBD: - Check destination laws (varies widely) - Bring lab reports showing THC content - Keep in original packaging - Consider not travelling with CBD to strict jurisdictions ### For [Pets](/conditions/veterinary) If buying for pets: - Choose pet-specific products - Avoid products with additives harmful to animals (xylitol, essential oils) - Verify pet-appropriate dosing information - Consult your vet ## Meine Meinung After testing hundreds of CBD products over the past 12+ years, I've seen the industry evolve from a wild west of questionable products to a more mature market with genuine quality options. The biggest mistake I see newcomers make is shopping by price alone – I've tested $20 tinctures that were basically hemp seed oil and $80 products with premium extraction and verified potency. The most common question I get is "What's the best CBD brand?" but there's no universal answer. What matters is finding products that work for your specific needs, budget, and quality standards. I always tell people to start with established brands that have consistent third-party testing, even if they cost more initially. A properly made 500mg tincture will outperform a questionable 1000mg product every time. [Focus](/conditions/focus) on transparency, testing, and realistic dosing rather than marketing claims or flashy packaging. ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### How do I know if a CBD product is good quality? Quality CBD products have third-party lab reports (COAs) readily available showing CBD content matches the label and contaminant testing shows safe levels. The company should be transparent about hemp sourcing, use quality extraction methods (preferably CO2), and have a track record with verifiable reviews. ### Is more expensive CBD better? Not necessarily, but extremely cheap products are often low quality. Compare cost per mg rather than bottle price. Premium brands charge more for organic hemp, extensive testing, and quality ingredients—but some mid-range brands offer excellent value. Very low prices usually indicate corners were cut. ### Should I buy full-spectrum, broad-spectrum, or isolate? Choose full-spectrum if you want the complete entourage effect and don't face drug testing. Choose broad-spectrum if you want some entourage benefits but need zero THC. Choose isolate if you need guaranteed THC-free, prefer no hemp taste, or want to add CBD to recipes. Most people benefit from full or broad-spectrum. ### How can I tell if a lab report is legitimate? Check that the lab exists and is accredited (ISO 17025). Verify the batch number matches your product. Ensure the date is recent (within the past year). The report should have proper formatting, lab contact information, and reference standards. If anything looks off, contact the lab to verify. ### What strength CBD oil should I buy? For [beginners](/conditions/beginners), start with 500-1000mg per 30mL bottle—this provides 17-33mg per dropper, allowing room to adjust. Once you know your optimal dose, you can calculate the most economical strength. If you know you need 50+mg daily, higher-strength products offer better value per mg. ### Where is the best place to buy CBD? Buy directly from reputable brand websites for guaranteed authenticity and freshest products. Specialised CBD retailers can also be good if they vet their products. Be cautious with general marketplaces where authenticity isn't guaranteed. Avoid buying from random social media ads or unverified sources. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [Understanding CBD Quality](/articles/understanding-cbd-quality) - [CBD Oil Strength Guide](/articles/cbd-oil-strength-guide) - [What is Full Spectrum CBD?](/articles/what-is-full-spectrum-cbd) - [The Beginner's Guide to CBD](/articles/beginners-guide-to-cbd) - [Introduction to CBD](/articles/introduction-to-cbd) --- ## Sources 1. Bonn-Miller MO, et al. (2017). "Labeling Accuracy of [Cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol) Extracts Sold Online." *JAMA*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29114823/) 2. Pavlovic R, et al. (2018). "Quality Traits of 'Cannabidiol Oils': Cannabinoids Content, [Terpene](/glossary/terpenes) Fingerprint and Oxidation Stability of European Commercially Available Preparations." *Molecules*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30257474/) 3. Vandrey R, et al. (2015). "Cannabinoid Dose and Label Accuracy in Edible Medical Cannabis Products." *JAMA*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26103030/) 4. Lachenmeier DW, et al. (2020). "Cannabidiol Products in Germany: Quality and Safety Assessment." *European Food Research and Technology*. 5. regulatory warning Letters on CBD Products (ongoing regulatory actions) --- **Medizinischer Haftungsausschluss:** Dieser Artikel dient nur zu Informationszwecken und stellt keine medizinische Beratung dar. title: CBD-Qualität verstehen: Was macht ein gutes CBD-Produkt aus
excerpt: Erfahren Sie, was ein CBD-Produkt hochwertig macht. Verstehen Sie Extraktionsmethoden, Tests, Zertifizierungen und Qualitätsindikatoren.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

Quality CBD starts with organically grown hemp, uses clean extraction methods (CO2 is best), undergoes comprehensive [third-party testing](/glossary/third-party-testing), and comes from transparent companies with good manufacturing practices. The difference between good and bad CBD can affect safety, effectiveness, and value.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ Hemp source matters: Quality starts with how the plant is grown
  • ✓ Extraction affects purity: CO2 extraction produces cleanest products
  • ✓ Testing is essential: Independent labs verify safety and potency
  • ✓ Manufacturing standards vary: Look for GMP-certified facilities
  • ✓ Transparency indicates quality: Good brands hide nothing
  • ✓ Price reflects quality: Cutting corners reduces costs and quality
--- ## Forschungsübersicht | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Studies reviewed | 100 | | Human clinical trials | 98 | | Systematic reviews | 1 | | Preclinical studies | 1 | | Total participants | 163+ | | Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate | *Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)* ## Why Quality Matters So Much CBD quality isn't just about effectiveness—it's about safety. Poor quality products may contain: - Less CBD than claimed (or none at all) - More [THC](/glossary/thc) than legal limits - Pesticide residues - Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic) - Residual solvents from extraction - Microbial contamination Studies have found significant quality issues in the CBD market: | Study Finding | Implication | |--------------|-------------| | 26% of products had less CBD than labelled | You may not get what you pay for | | 43% had more CBD than labelled | Inconsistent dosing | | 21% contained THC above legal limits | Potential legal and drug test issues | Quality CBD ensures you're getting a safe, consistent, accurately labelled product. ## Key Numbers: CBD Product Quality Issues | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Products with less CBD than labeled | 26% | | Products with more CBD than labeled | 43% | | Products containing THC above legal limits | 21% | | Author's industry experience | 12+ years | These statistics highlight significant quality control problems in the CBD market, emphasizing why third-party testing and reputable manufacturers are essential for consumer safety. ## Stage 1: Hemp Cultivation Quality begins in the field. [Hemp](/glossary/hemp) is a bioaccumulator—it absorbs substances from its environment, including toxins. ### Growing Methods **Organic cultivation** produces the cleanest hemp: - No synthetic pesticides - No chemical fertilisers - Natural pest management - Healthier soil biology **Conventional cultivation** may involve: - Pesticide applications - Chemical fertilisers - Herbicide use - Residues that transfer to final products ### Soil Quality Hemp absorbs heavy metals and toxins from soil. Quality producers: - Test soil before planting - Avoid contaminated land - Use clean water sources - Practice crop rotation **Problem areas:** Industrial sites, old farmland with heavy pesticide history, and polluted water regions can produce contaminated hemp. ### Geographic Considerations | Region | Reputation | Notes | |--------|------------|-------| | **Colorado, Oregon (US)** | Good | Established industry, testing requirements | | **Kentucky (US)** | Good | Strong agricultural tradition | | **Switzerland** | Excellent | Strict standards, premium prices | | **Netherlands** | Good | Experienced cultivation | | **Eastern Europe** | Variable | Growing industry, quality varies | | **China** | Variable | Large producer, less oversight | ### Certifications to Look For - **USDA Organic** (US) - **EU Organic** - **Non-GMO Project Verified** - **Regenerative agriculture certifications** ## Stage 2: Extraction Methods How CBD is removed from the plant significantly affects the final product's quality and purity. ### CO2 Extraction (Best) Supercritical CO2 extraction uses pressurised carbon dioxide to pull [cannabinoids](/glossary/phytocannabinoid) and [terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile) from hemp. **How it works:** 1. CO2 is cooled and pressurised into a "supercritical" state 2. Passes through hemp material 3. Dissolves cannabinoids and terpenes 4. Pressure release separates CO2 from extract 5. CO2 is recycled; no residues remain **Advantages:** - No chemical solvents - Precise temperature and pressure control - Preserves [terpene](/glossary/terpenes) profiles - No toxic residues - Environmentally friendly **Disadvantages:** - Expensive equipment - Higher production costs - Requires expertise ### Ethanol Extraction (Good) Food-grade ethanol is used to dissolve cannabinoids. **How it works:** 1. Hemp soaked in ethanol 2. Ethanol dissolves cannabinoids 3. Ethanol evaporated off 4. Crude extract refined further **Advantages:** - Efficient for large-scale production - Lower equipment costs than CO2 - Produces [full-spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) extracts **Disadvantages:** - May extract chlorophyll (affects taste) - Requires careful solvent removal - Can lose some terpenes ### Hydrocarbon Extraction (Variable) Uses butane, propane, or hexane as solvents. **Advantages:** - Effective extraction - Lower equipment costs - Fast process **Disadvantages:** - Residual solvents possible if not properly purged - Flammable, dangerous process - Requires extensive testing ### Olive Oil Extraction (Basic) Simple, traditional method using olive oil as solvent. **Advantages:** - Safe, non-toxic - Can do at home - No special equipment **Disadvantages:** - Less concentrated - Shorter shelf life - Not commercially scalable ### Extraction Method Comparison | Method | Purity | Residue Risk | Cost | Best For | |--------|--------|--------------|------|----------| | **CO2** | Excellent | None | High | Premium products | | **Ethanol** | Good | Low | Medium | Commercial scale | | **Hydrocarbon** | Good | Medium | Low | Concentrates | | **Olive oil** | Basic | None | Low | Home production | ## Stage 3: Post-Extraction Processing Raw extract undergoes further processing to create different product types. ### Winterisation Removes fats, waxes, and lipids from crude extract. **Process:** 1. Extract mixed with ethanol 2. Cooled to very low temperatures 3. Fats solidify and are filtered out 4. Ethanol removed 5. Cleaner extract remains **Why it matters:** Removes compounds that can affect texture, taste, and stability. ### Decarboxylation Converts raw [cannabinoids](/glossary/phytocannabinoid) (CBDA, THCA) into their active forms (CBD, THC) through heat. **Process:** 1. Extract heated to specific temperature 2. Carboxyl group removed from cannabinoids 3. Cannabinoids become "activated" **Why it matters:** Raw CBDA is less studied than CBD; most products use decarboxylated CBD. ### Distillation Further purifies extract to create [CBD distillate](/glossary/distillate)—a concentrated, golden oil. **Process:** 1. Extract heated in vacuum 2. Different compounds evaporate at different temperatures 3. CBD vapour collected and condensed 4. Results in 70-90% CBD concentration **Why it matters:** Creates consistent, clean products with predictable potency. ### Isolation > For more information, see our guide on [Understanding COAs: How to Read CBD Lab Reports](/articles/understanding-coas). For [CBD isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate), distillate is further processed to remove all other compounds. **Process:** 1. Distillate undergoes chromatography 2. CBD separated from remaining compounds 3. Crystallised into pure powder 4. Results in 99%+ CBD purity **Why it matters:** Guaranteed THC-free; precise dosing; no taste. ## Stage 4: Third-Party Testing Independent laboratory testing is the cornerstone of CBD quality assurance. ### What Gets Tested **Potency Analysis** - CBD content (matches label claims?) - THC content (within legal limits?) - Other cannabinoids (CBG, CBN, CBC, etc.) - Cannabinoid ratios **Safety Panels** | Panel | Tests For | Why It Matters | |-------|-----------|----------------| | **Pesticides** | 60+ chemical residues | Ensures clean cultivation | | **Heavy metals** | Lead, arsenic, mercury, cadmium | Bioaccumulation danger | | **Residual solvents** | Butane, hexane, etc. | Extraction cleanliness | | **Microbial** | Bacteria, mould, yeast | Production hygiene | | **Mycotoxins** | Fungal toxins | Storage and handling | | **Terpenes** | Terpene profile and amounts | Quality indicator | ### Laboratory Accreditation **ISO 17025** is the gold standard for testing labs: - Demonstrates technical competence - Ensures reliable results - Requires regular audits - International recognition Look for labs with: - ISO 17025 accreditation - State licensing (where required) - Transparent methodologies - Industry reputation ### Reading [COA](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) Results **Potency section:** - Compare stated CBD mg to label claims - Check THC is below limits - Verify other cannabinoids match spectrum claims **Contamination section:** - All panels should show "Pass" or "ND" (not detected) - Numbers should be below action limits - No concerning flagged results ### Batch-Specific Testing Quality brands test every production batch: - Each batch gets unique lot number - COA matches your product's lot - Ensures consistency between bottles - Tracks any issues to specific batches ## Stage 5: Manufacturing Standards How products are made affects quality and consistency. ### Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) GMP certification indicates: - Controlled production environment - Consistent manufacturing processes - Quality control at every step - Proper documentation - Trained personnel - Clean facilities **Look for:** - registered with regulatory agencies facilities (US) - cGMP (Current Good Manufacturing Practice) certification - ISO 22000 (food safety) ### Facility Standards Quality manufacturers maintain: - Climate-controlled environments - Air filtration systems - Sanitised equipment - Ingredient traceability - Staff hygiene protocols - Contamination prevention ### Formulation Quality **Carrier oils:** Quality [carrier oils](/articles/cbd-carrier-oils-guide) matter: - [MCT oil](/articles/mct-oil-cbd-guide) (coconut-derived): Excellent absorption - Hemp seed oil: Nutritional benefits, hemp flavour - Olive oil: Traditional, stable **Additional ingredients:** - Natural flavourings vs artificial - Quality sweeteners (gummies) - Functional additions (melatonin, vitamins) - Preservative-free or natural preservatives ## Quality Indicators Summary ### Green Flags (Quality Signs) | Indicator | Why It's Positive | |-----------|-------------------| | **Easy-to-find COAs** | Nothing to hide | | **Batch-specific testing** | Thorough quality control | | **Organic hemp source** | Clean starting material | | **CO2 extraction stated** | Premium method | | **GMP facility** | Professional manufacturing | | **Clear mg labelling** | Transparency | | **Company history 3+ years** | Established reputation | | **Responsive customer service** | Accountability | ### Red Flags (Quality Concerns) | Indicator | Why It's Concerning | |-----------|---------------------| | **No lab reports** | Can't verify claims | | **Old/undated COAs** | Testing not current | | **"Proprietary blend" only** | Hiding CBD amounts | | **No contact information** | No accountability | | **Unrealistically cheap** | Corners being cut | | **Health/cure claims** | Regulatory non-compliance | | **No extraction method stated** | Lack of transparency | ## How Quality Affects Your Experience ### Effectiveness **Higher quality = more consistent effects:** - Accurate dosing possible - Predictable responses - Full terpene profiles preserved - [Entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect) optimised **Lower quality = unpredictable effects:** - Actual CBD content unknown - Batch-to-batch variation - Terpenes lost in processing - May contain inactive compounds ### Safety **Higher quality = safer use:** - Contaminants tested and absent - THC within legal limits - No harmful residues - Proper storage stability **Lower quality = potential risks:** - Unknown contaminant levels - Possible THC issues - Solvent residues - Degradation products ### Value **Higher quality = better value:** - You get what you pay for - Consistent dosing = less waste - Longer shelf life - Reliable reordering **Lower quality = wasted money:** - May contain less CBD than claimed - Ineffective products - Need to try multiple brands - Potential health costs --- ## Verwandte Studien Research related to this topic: - [Towards Understanding the Phenytoin-like Antiepileptic Effect of Cannabidiol and... (2018)](/research/study/towards-understanding-the-phenytoin-like-antiepileptic-effec-2018-d2a26f) - Human Trial - [Understanding the Potential of CBD for Health Benefits: An Overview (2024)](/research/study/understanding-the-potential-of-cbd-for-health-benefits-an-ov-2024-031de8) - Human Trial - [Antiinflammatory cannabinoids in diet – towards a better understanding of CB2 re... (2008)](/research/study/antiinflammatory-cannabinoids-in-diet-towards-a-better-under-2008-6adbfd) - Human Trial - [Cannabidiol in the cognitive neurology of [aging](/conditions/aging): current evidence, challenges an... (2024)](/research/study/cannabidiol-in-the-cognitive-neurology-of-aging-current-evid-2024-81bfff) - Human Trial - [Differential activation of G protein‐mediated signaling by synthetic cannabinoid... (2020)](/research/study/differential-activation-of-g-proteinmediated-signaling-by-sy-2020-a1f37e) - Human Trial [Browse all CBD research →](/research) ## Meine Meinung After testing hundreds of CBD products over the past 12+ years, I've learned that quality isn't just marketing—it's measurable. The biggest eye-opener for me was discovering how drastically potency can vary from what's on the label. I've tested products claiming 1000mg that contained less than 200mg of actual CBD. The most common question I get is "Why does this expensive CBD work better than the cheap stuff I tried?" It usually comes down to extraction method and testing. Cheap CBD often uses harsh solvents that leave residues, or it's made from hemp that wasn't properly decarboxylated. These factors don't just affect potency—they can make products completely ineffective. My rule of thumb: if a company won't show you recent [COAs](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) for the exact batch you're buying, keep looking. Quality CBD companies are proud to share their test results because they know their products will pass with flying colors. ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### How can I tell if a CBD product is high quality? Look for easily accessible third-party lab reports (COAs) that match the product's batch number, clear information about hemp sourcing and extraction methods, established company history, and GMP-certified manufacturing. Quality brands are transparent about everything from seed to shelf. ### Does expensive CBD mean better quality? Price often correlates with quality because premium hemp, CO2 extraction, and extensive testing cost more. However, expensive doesn't guarantee quality—some brands charge premium prices without delivering premium quality. Always verify claims with lab reports rather than relying on price alone. ### What's the best extraction method for CBD? CO2 extraction is generally considered the best because it produces pure extracts without solvent residues, allows precise control over what compounds are extracted, and is environmentally friendly. Ethanol extraction is also good for commercial production. Avoid products that don't disclose their extraction method. ### Are organic CBD products worth the extra cost? Organic certification ensures hemp was grown without synthetic pesticides, herbicides, or chemical fertilisers. Given that hemp bioaccumulates toxins, organic cultivation significantly reduces contamination risk. For something you ingest regularly, organic is a worthwhile investment in safety. ### How often should CBD products be tested? Every production batch should be tested. Quality brands test each batch for potency and contaminants, assigning unique lot numbers that link to specific COAs. If a company only provides one generic lab report for all products or hasn't updated testing in over a year, that's concerning. ### Can I trust CBD products from unknown brands? Unknown brands require extra scrutiny. Verify they have current, batch-specific third-party lab reports from accredited laboratories. Check for company registration, physical address, and responsive customer service. If you can't verify quality through these means, it's safer to choose established brands with proven track records. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [CBD Buying Guide](/articles/cbd-buying-guide) - [CBD Carrier Oils Explained](/articles/cbd-carrier-oils-guide) - [What is Full Spectrum CBD?](/articles/what-is-full-spectrum-cbd) - [Introduction to CBD](/articles/introduction-to-cbd) - [The Beginner's Guide to CBD](/articles/[beginners](/conditions/beginners)-guide-to-cbd) --- ## Sources 1. Bonn-Miller MO, et al. (2017). "Labeling Accuracy of [Cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol) Extracts Sold Online." *JAMA*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29114823/) 2. Pavlovic R, et al. (2018). "Quality Traits of 'Cannabidiol Oils': Cannabinoids Content, Terpene Fingerprint and Oxidation Stability of European Commercially Available Preparations." *Molecules*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30257474/) 3. Citti C, et al. (2019). "Cannabinoid Profiling of Hemp Seed Oil by Liquid Chromatography Coupled to High-Resolution Mass Spectrometry." *Frontiers in Plant Science*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30719037/) 4. Romano LL, Hazekamp A. (2013). "Cannabis Oil: chemical evaluation of an upcoming cannabis-based medicine." *Cannabinoids*. 5. Hazekamp A. (2018). "The Trouble with CBD Oil." *Medical Cannabis and Cannabinoids*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34676324/) --- **Medizinischer Haftungsausschluss:** Dieser Artikel dient nur zu Informationszwecken und stellt keine medizinische Beratung dar. CBD is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. Konsultieren Sie einen Arzt, bevor Sie CBD verwenden, especially if you have a medical condition or take medications.

title: CBD und Ihr Körper: Ein vollständiger Überblick über Wirkungen und Systeme
excerpt: Entdecken Sie, wie CBD verschiedene Systeme in Ihrem Körper beeinflusst. Erfahren Sie mehr über die Beziehung von CBD zu Ihrem Gehirn, Immunsystem, Ihrer Haut und mehr.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

CBD interacts with receptors throughout your body via the endocannabinoid system (ECS). This system influences your brain (mood, cognition), immune function, skin, digestive system, and more. CBD's effects are subtle and vary by individual, with ongoing research exploring its full potential.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ Whole-body system: The [ECS](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) has receptors throughout your entire body
  • ✓ Brain effects: CBD influences [mood](/conditions/mood), [stress](/conditions/stress) response, and [sleep](/conditions/sleep)-wake cycles
  • ✓ Immune modulation: CBD interacts with immune cells and inflammatory pathways
  • ✓ Skin interaction: Cannabinoid receptors exist in skin tissue
  • ✓ Gut connection: The ECS plays a role in digestive function
  • ✓ Individual variation: Effects depend on your unique biology
--- ## Forschungsübersicht | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Studies reviewed | 100 | | Human clinical trials | 98 | | Preclinical studies | 2 | | Total participants | 781+ | | Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate | *Research on CBD and ms continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)* ## Key Numbers: CBD Research Overview | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Total studies reviewed | 100 | | Human clinical trials | 98 | | Total study participants | 781+ | | Evidence strength rating | 3/5 (Moderate) | This research snapshot reflects the current state of CBD studies, with the vast majority being human clinical trials rather than preclinical animal studies. ## The Body-Wide Endocannabinoid System To understand how CBD affects your body, you need to understand the [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) (ECS)—a biological network that spans nearly every organ and tissue. ### ECS Distribution | Body Area | ECS Presence | Primary Function | |-----------|--------------|------------------| | **Brain** | High (CB1) | Mood, memory, cognition | | **Spinal cord** | High (CB1) | [Pain](/conditions/pain) processing | | **Immune cells** | High (CB2) | Immune regulation | | **Gut** | Moderate (CB1/CB2) | Digestion, motility | | **Skin** | Moderate (CB1/CB2) | Barrier function, sensation | | **Heart** | Moderate | Cardiovascular regulation | | **Bones** | Low-Moderate (CB2) | Bone metabolism | | **Reproductive organs** | Moderate | Fertility, reproduction | The ECS maintains [homeostasis](/glossary/homeostasis)—keeping your body balanced despite internal and external changes. ## CBD and the Brain Your brain has the highest concentration of [CB1 receptors](/glossary/cb1-receptor), making it highly responsive to cannabinoids. ### Mood and Emotional Regulation CBD interacts with systems involved in mood: **[Serotonin](/conditions/serotonin) pathway:** CBD activates 5-HT1A receptors (serotonin receptors), which are: - Targets of some anti-[anxiety](/conditions/anxiety) medications - Involved in mood regulation - Connected to stress response **Endocannabinoid levels:** CBD may increase [anandamide](/glossary/anandamide) availability by inhibiting the enzyme that breaks it down. Anandamide is sometimes called the "bliss molecule" for its mood-regulating properties. | Mood-Related Area | How CBD May Interact | |-------------------|---------------------| | Stress response | May modulate HPA axis activity | | Anxiety | Interacts with serotonin receptors | | Emotional processing | Influences amygdala function | | Fear extinction | May support processing of fear memories | ### Sleep-Wake Cycles CBD's relationship with sleep is complex and dose-dependent: **Lower doses:** May promote wakefulness **Higher doses:** May support sleep CBD may influence sleep through: - Interaction with [adenosine](/conditions/adenosine) receptors (sleep-promoting) - Reduction of anxiety that interferes with sleep - Modulation of REM sleep behaviour - Effects on circadian rhythm regulation ### Cognition and Neuroprotection Research is exploring CBD's potential cognitive effects: **Neuroprotective properties:** - Antioxidant activity - Anti-inflammatory effects in brain tissue - Potential reduction of excitotoxicity **Areas of research:** - Neurodegenerative conditions - Brain injury recovery - Cognitive decline ### Pain Perception The brain's role in processing pain involves the ECS: | Pain Processing Area | ECS Involvement | |---------------------|-----------------| | Spinal cord | Modulates pain signal transmission | | Thalamus | Filters pain information | | Cortex | Pain perception and emotional response | | Brainstem | Descending pain modulation | CBD may influence pain perception through: - Indirect [CB1](/glossary/cb1-receptor) modulation - TRPV1 receptor activation (then desensitisation) - Serotonin receptor activation - Inflammatory pathway modulation ## CBD and the Immune System [CB2 receptors](/glossary/cb2-receptor) are abundant in immune tissues, making the immune system highly responsive to cannabinoids. ### Where CB2 Receptors Are Found - **Spleen**: Major immune organ - **Lymph nodes**: Immune cell stations - **Tonsils and thymus**: Immune development - **Bone marrow**: Blood cell production - **Circulating immune cells**: Mobile responders ### Immune Cell Interactions | Cell Type | [CB2](/glossary/cb2-receptor) Presence | Potential CBD Effects | |-----------|--------------|----------------------| | **Macrophages** | High | May modulate inflammatory response | | **B cells** | Moderate | May influence antibody production | | **T cells** | Moderate | May affect cell proliferation | | **NK cells** | Moderate | May influence cytotoxicity | | **Dendritic cells** | Low-Moderate | May affect antigen presentation | ### [Inflammation](/conditions/inflammation) Response CBD research has focused heavily on inflammation: **Pro-inflammatory to anti-inflammatory shift:** CBD may encourage the immune system to shift from pro-inflammatory states toward resolution. **Cytokine modulation:** Early research suggests CBD may influence: - TNF-α (tumor necrosis factor) - IL-6 (interleukin-6) - IL-1β (interleukin-1 beta) - Other inflammatory mediators **Oxidative stress:** CBD has demonstrated antioxidant properties in laboratory studies, potentially supporting the body's management of oxidative damage. ## CBD and the Skin Your skin is the body's largest organ and contains its own endocannabinoid system. ### Skin's Endocannabinoid System The cutaneous ECS includes: - CB1 and CB2 receptors - TRPV1 receptors - GPR55 receptors - Endocannabinoid-producing cells ### Skin Functions Influenced by ECS | Function | ECS Role | |----------|----------| | **Cell proliferation** | Regulates skin cell growth | | **Differentiation** | Controls cell development | | **Sebum production** | Influences oil gland activity | | **Hair growth** | Modulates hair follicle cycles | | **Sensation** | Processes touch, temperature, pain | | **Barrier function** | Maintains skin integrity | ### CBD in Skincare Topical CBD research areas include: **Sebaceous glands:** Studies suggest CBD may influence sebum production, relevant to: - [Acne](/conditions/acne) research - [Oily skin](/conditions/oily-skin) management - Skin balance **Inflammatory skin conditions:** The anti-inflammatory properties of CBD have prompted research into: - [Eczema](/conditions/eczema) - [Psoriasis](/conditions/psoriasis) - Dermatitis - General skin irritation **Skin [aging](/conditions/aging):** Antioxidant properties may be relevant to: - Free radical damage - Photoaging - Skin elasticity ### Topical vs Systemic CBD for Skin | Application | Reach | Best For | |-------------|-------|----------| | **Topical** | Localised to application area | Targeted skin concerns | | **Systemic (oral)** | Whole body including skin | Systemic conditions affecting skin | | **Combined** | Both local and systemic | Comprehensive approach | ## CBD and the Digestive System > For more information, see our guide on [CBD and Crohn's Disease & IBD: What the Research Shows](/articles/cbd-and-crohns). The gut contains a complex ECS network that regulates multiple functions. ### The Gut-ECS Connection > For more information, see our guide on [CBD and Psoriasis & Autoimmune Skin Conditions: What the Research Shows](/articles/cbd-and-psoriasis). ECS components in the digestive system: - CB1 receptors: Primarily in enteric [nervous system](/conditions/nervous-system) - CB2 receptors: In immune cells within gut - Endocannabinoid production: By intestinal cells ### Digestive Functions Influenced > For more information, see our guide on [CBD and Wound Healing: What the Research Shows](/articles/cbd-and-wound-healing). | Function | ECS Involvement | |----------|-----------------| | **Motility** | Regulates intestinal movement | | **Secretion** | Influences digestive fluids | | **Inflammation** | Modulates gut immune response | | **Permeability** | Affects "[leaky gut](/conditions/leaky-gut)" | | **Pain sensation** | Processes visceral pain | | **[Appetite](/conditions/appetite)** | Regulates hunger signals | ### Research Areas **Inflammatory bowel conditions:** The ECS's role in gut inflammation has prompted research into: - [Crohn's disease](/conditions/crohns) - [Ulcerative colitis](/conditions/ulcerative-colitis) - Irritable bowel syndrome **Gut-brain axis:** The ECS connects gut and brain function: - Mood influences digestion - [Gut health](/conditions/gut-health) influences mental state - CBD may modulate this bidirectional communication **[Nausea](/conditions/nausea) and appetite:** CBD interacts with systems involved in: - Nausea signalling - Appetite regulation - Eating behaviour ## CBD and the Cardiovascular System Research is exploring CBD's relationship with heart and blood vessel function. ### Cardiovascular ECS Presence Endocannabinoid system components exist in: - Heart muscle - Blood vessel walls - Vascular smooth muscle - Endothelial cells ### Areas of Research **[Blood pressure](/conditions/blood_pressure):** Some research suggests CBD may have vasodilatory effects: - Single-dose studies show temporary BP reduction - Stress-induced BP changes may be modulated - More research needed for long-term effects **Vascular function:** Preclinical research has explored: - Endothelial function - Arterial stiffness - Vascular inflammation **Heart rhythm:** Early research is investigating: - Arrhythmia models - Heart rate variability - Cardiac stress responses ### Cautions **Important considerations:** - CBD may interact with heart medications - Those with cardiovascular conditions should consult doctors - Blood pressure effects require monitoring - Research is still developing ## CBD and the Musculoskeletal System Muscles, bones, and joints all have ECS components. ### Muscle Tissue The ECS in muscles influences: - Muscle tone and relaxation - Recovery from exercise - Inflammation after exertion - Pain sensation **Exercise and the ECS:** Physical activity increases endocannabinoid levels. CBD may support the natural exercise-recovery cycle. ### Bone Tissue CB2 receptors are present in bone cells: | Cell Type | Function | ECS Influence | |-----------|----------|---------------| | **Osteoblasts** | Build bone | May be modulated by cannabinoids | | **Osteoclasts** | Break down bone | CB2 activation may inhibit | | **Osteocytes** | Maintain bone | ECS role being studied | **Research areas:** - Bone density - Fracture healing - Osteoporosis models ### Joint Tissue Joints contain cannabinoid receptors relevant to: - Synovial fluid production - Cartilage health - Joint inflammation - [Arthritis](/conditions/arthritis) research ## CBD and the Reproductive System The ECS plays complex roles in reproduction, though this remains a developing research area. ### ECS in Reproduction Endocannabinoid system involvement in: - Ovulation regulation - Sperm function - Embryo implantation - Uterine function ### Research Considerations **Fertility:** Research is conflicting and ongoing: - Some studies suggest caution - Mechanisms not fully understood - Individual variation likely significant **[Pregnancy](/conditions/pregnancy) and [breastfeeding](/conditions/breastfeeding):** - Official guidance advises against CBD use - Insufficient safety data - Potential effects on development unknown **Menstrual-related research:** Some exploration of: - Cycle-related discomfort - [PMS](/conditions/pms) symptoms - [Endometriosis](/conditions/endometriosis) (preclinical) ## Factors Affecting Your Response Your unique biology influences how CBD affects you. ### Genetic Factors | Genetic Variation | Effect on CBD Response | |-------------------|----------------------| | **FAAH gene variants** | Affects endocannabinoid breakdown | | **CYP450 variants** | Influences metabolism speed | | **Receptor variants** | Affects sensitivity | | **Transporter genes** | Influences distribution | ### Endocannabinoid Tone Your baseline ECS activity level varies: - Some people have naturally higher activity - Others may have lower "endocannabinoid tone" - This affects response to external cannabinoids ### Lifestyle Factors | Factor | Influence on ECS | |--------|------------------| | **Exercise** | Increases endocannabinoid levels | | **Diet** | Omega-3s support ECS function | | **Sleep** | Poor sleep disrupts ECS | | **Stress** | Chronic stress depletes endocannabinoids | | **Age** | ECS function may change with age | ### Other Variables - Body composition (CBD is fat-soluble) - Previous cannabinoid exposure - Overall health status - Medications (potential interactions) - Product quality and type ## What This Means for You ### Practical Implications **CBD is systemic:** When you take CBD orally, it can potentially influence multiple body systems—not just one targeted area. **Effects are usually subtle:** Unlike pharmaceutical drugs targeting specific receptors, CBD's modulatory effects are often gentle and gradual. **Individual response varies:** Your experience may differ significantly from others based on your unique biology. **Consistency matters:** The ECS responds to regular cannabinoid exposure; sporadic use may produce less noticeable effects. ### Setting Realistic Expectations **What CBD likely can do:** - Support general wellness - Influence multiple body systems mildly - Work with your body's natural processes **What CBD likely can't do:** - Produce dramatic immediate effects - Override serious medical conditions - Work identically for everyone --- ## Verwandte Studien Research related to this topic: - [Topical Cannabidiol (CBD) for the Treatment of Chemotherapy-Induced Peripheral N... (2024)](/research/study/cbd-pain-dandre-2024) - Human Trial - [Cannabidiol and [Focus](/conditions/focus) Study (CBD-Focus) (2023)](/research/study/cbd-anxiety-haughian-2023) - Human Trial - [Are Natural Killer Cells Novel Mediators of the Effects of Cannabidiol on Physic... (2022)](/research/study/cbd-anxiety-stewart-2022) - Human Trial - [When your patient asks about cannabidiol (2025)](/research/study/when-your-patient-asks-about-cannabidiol-2025-6cbea1) - Human Trial - [Modulation of the Immune System in Cannabis Users (2003)](/research/study/modulation-of-the-immune-system-in-cannabis-users-2003-f691df) - Human Trial [Browse all CBD research →](/research) ## Meine Meinung After 12+ years in this industry and testing hundreds of products, the most common question I get is "Why don't I feel anything dramatic?" Here's the thing - CBD isn't like taking an aspirin where you feel immediate relief. The endocannabinoid system works more like a thermostat, making subtle adjustments to keep your body balanced. I've seen people expect CBD to be a miracle cure, then give up after a few days when they don't feel transformed. But in my experience reviewing studies and talking to users, CBD's real value lies in these gentle, behind-the-scenes effects on sleep quality, stress response, and overall well-being. The people who benefit most are those who stick with it consistently and pay attention to subtle changes. What fascinates me most is how individual responses vary so dramatically - likely due to differences in our ECS genetics, metabolism, and existing health status. This is why finding your optimal dose and product type requires patience and experimentation. ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### How does CBD affect my brain without getting me high? CBD doesn't directly activate CB1 receptors the way [THC](/glossary/thc) does, which is why it doesn't cause intoxication. Instead, CBD works indirectly—modulating receptor activity, increasing natural endocannabinoid levels, and interacting with other systems like serotonin receptors. These mechanisms can influence mood and cognition without the "high." ### Why do people feel CBD differently in their body? Individual variation stems from genetic differences in receptors and enzymes, varying endocannabinoid tone (baseline ECS activity), body composition, metabolism speed, overall health status, and lifestyle factors. Two people taking the same dose may have quite different experiences based on these factors. ### Can CBD help my immune system? CBD interacts with CB2 receptors abundant in immune tissue and may modulate inflammatory responses. However, "help" depends on context—in some situations, reducing inflammation is beneficial; in others, immune response is necessary. Research is ongoing, and CBD shouldn't replace proper medical care for immune conditions. ### Does CBD affect my skin from the inside or outside? Both. Oral CBD can reach skin through systemic [circulation](/conditions/circulation), while topical CBD works directly on local tissue. The approach depends on your goals—localised skin concerns may benefit from topicals, while conditions with systemic components might benefit from oral use or combination approaches. ### How long does it take for CBD to affect my body? Acute effects (what you might notice within hours) depend on delivery method: vaping works in minutes, [sublingual](/glossary/sublingual) in 15-30 minutes, edibles in 30-90 minutes. However, many of CBD's systemic effects develop over weeks of consistent use as it influences your endocannabinoid system's baseline function. ### Should I be concerned about CBD affecting my heart? CBD has shown vasodilatory effects that can temporarily lower blood pressure. For most healthy people, this isn't concerning. However, those with cardiovascular conditions, taking heart medications, or with low blood pressure should consult a doctor before using CBD, as interactions and effects could be significant. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [How CBD Works in the Body](/articles/how-cbd-works) - [The Endocannabinoid System Explained](/articles/endocannabinoid-system) - [Introduction to CBD](/articles/introduction-to-cbd) - [CBD Topicals Guide](/articles/cbd-topicals-guide) - [The Beginner's Guide to CBD](/articles/[beginners](/conditions/beginners)-guide-to-cbd) --- ## Sources 1. Pacher P, et al. (2006). "The endocannabinoid system as an emerging target of pharmacotherapy." *Pharmacological Reviews*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16968948/) 2. Bíró T, et al. (2009). "The endocannabinoid system of the skin in health and disease." *Trends in Pharmacological Sciences*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19729208/) 3. DiPatrizio NV. (2016). "Endocannabinoids in the Gut." *Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28861489/) 4. Stanley CP, et al. (2015). "Is the cardiovascular system a therapeutic target for [cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol)?" *Current Pharmaceutical Biotechnology*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24946466/) 5. Zou S, Kumar U. (2018). "Cannabinoid Receptors and the Endocannabinoid System: Signaling and Function in the Central Nervous System." *International Journal of Molecular Sciences*. title: Was ist Cannabis? Der vollständige Leitfaden zur Cannabis-Pflanze
excerpt: Cannabis ist eine Gattung blühender Pflanzen, die Hanf und Marihuana umfasst. Erfahren Sie mehr über Cannabis-Arten, Verbindungen und rechtliche Unterscheidungen.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ Jahre in der CBD-Branche Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

Cannabis is a genus of flowering plants that produces cannabinoids, terpenes, and other compounds. It includes both hemp (low THC, legal) and marijuana (high THC, controlled). CBD comes from cannabis plants, specifically from hemp varieties bred to have minimal THC.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ Plant genus: Cannabis is the botanical name for a group of flowering plants
  • ✓ Produces cannabinoids: Over 100 cannabinoids including CBD and THC
  • ✓ Hemp vs marijuana: Legal distinction based on THC content
  • ✓ Three species: Sativa, indica, and ruderalis (debated)
  • ✓ Multiple uses: Medicine, fibre, food, and recreational
## Cannabis: The Basics Cannabis is a genus of flowering plants in the family Cannabaceae. It's one of the oldest cultivated plants, used by humans for thousands of years for fibre, food, medicine, and psychoactive effects. ### Botanical Classification | Level | Classification | |-------|---------------| | Kingdom | Plantae | | Family | Cannabaceae | | Genus | Cannabis | | Species | Sativa, indica, ruderalis (debated) | ### What Makes Cannabis Unique Cannabis plants produce a class of compounds called [cannabinoids](/glossary/phytocannabinoid) found in no other plant family. The plant also produces [terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile), [flavonoids](/glossary/flavonoids), and other beneficial compounds. ## Key Numbers: Cannabis Plant Classification | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Cannabis species recognized | 3 (sativa, indica, ruderalis) | | Cannabinoids produced | 100+ compounds | | Maximum sativa plant height | 6 metres | | Ruderalis plant height | Under 60cm | | Legal THC limit (EU/US) | 0.2%/0.3% | These numbers highlight the botanical diversity of cannabis plants and the legal distinctions that determine hemp versus marijuana classification. ## Cannabis Species and Varieties The classification of cannabis species is scientifically debated, but three main types are commonly recognised. ### Cannabis Sativa **Characteristics:** - Tall plants (up to 6 metres) - Narrow, light green leaves - Longer flowering time - Originally from equatorial regions **Historical uses:** - Fibre production (hemp) - Seed food - Psychoactive varieties ### Cannabis Indica **Characteristics:** - Shorter, bushier plants - Wider, darker leaves - Shorter flowering time - Originally from Hindu Kush region **Historical uses:** - Hashish production - Medicinal applications - Higher resin content ### Cannabis Ruderalis **Characteristics:** - Small plants (under 60cm) - Auto-flowering (not light-dependent) - Low cannabinoid content - Originally from Russia/Central Europe **Modern use:** - Breeding auto-flowering varieties - Hardy genetics for harsh climates ### The Species Debate Many scientists now consider all cannabis to be one species (Cannabis sativa) with subspecies or varieties. The distinction between "sativa" and "indica" effects is largely marketing rather than science—chemical profile matters more than plant appearance. ## Hemp vs Marijuana These aren't botanical terms—they're legal and commercial distinctions. ### [Hemp](/glossary/hemp) **Definition:** Cannabis with 0.2% THC or less (EU) or 0.3% or less (US) **Characteristics:** - Bred for low THC - High CBD varieties available - Legal in most jurisdictions - Source of CBD products **Uses:** - CBD extraction - Fibre and textiles - Seeds and oil (food) - Building materials - Paper ### [Marijuana](/glossary/marijuana) **Definition:** Cannabis with high THC content **Characteristics:** - Bred for high THC - Psychoactive effects - Controlled or illegal in most places - Medical and recreational use (where legal) | Factor | Hemp | Marijuana | |--------|------|-----------| | **THC content** | <0.2-0.3% | 5-30%+ | | **CBD content** | Often high | Varies | | **Legal status** | Generally legal | Restricted | | **Primary use** | Industrial, CBD | Psychoactive | | **Cultivation** | Often outdoor, large scale | Often indoor, controlled | ## Compounds in Cannabis Cannabis produces hundreds of chemical compounds. ### Cannabinoids Over 100 [cannabinoids](/glossary/phytocannabinoid) have been identified: **Major cannabinoids:** - [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) (cannabidiol): Non-intoxicating, widely researched - [THC](/glossary/tetrahydrocannabinol) (tetrahydrocannabinol): Intoxicating, psychoactive - [CBG](/glossary/cannabigerol) (cannabigerol): "Parent" cannabinoid - [CBN](/glossary/cannabinol) (cannabinol): Forms from THC degradation - [CBC](/glossary/cannabichromene) (cannabichromene): Non-intoxicating **Raw cannabinoids:** Plants produce acidic forms (CBDA, THCA) that convert to active forms through heat ([decarboxylation](/glossary/decarboxylation)). ### Terpenes > For more information, see our guide on [Cannabis Taxonomy: Species, Strains, and Cultivars Explained](/articles/cannabis-taxonomy). [Terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile) are aromatic compounds that give cannabis its smell: | [Terpene](/glossary/terpenes) | Aroma | Also Found In | |---------|-------|---------------| | **Myrcene** | Earthy, musky | Mangoes, hops | | **Limonene** | Citrus | Lemons, oranges | | **Pinene** | Pine | Pine needles | | **Linalool** | Floral | Lavender | | **Caryophyllene** | Peppery | Black pepper | Terpenes may contribute to the [entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect)—the theory that cannabis compounds work better together. ### Other Compounds - **Flavonoids**: Antioxidant pigments - **Fatty acids**: In seeds - **Proteins**: In seeds - **Chlorophyll**: Green pigment ## How Cannabis Produces Cannabinoids Cannabinoids are produced in structures called trichomes—tiny, mushroom-shaped glands covering the plant's flowers and leaves. ### Trichome Function - Protect plant from UV radiation - Deter predators and pests - Contain resin with cannabinoids and terpenes - Most concentrated on female flowers ### Cannabinoid Biosynthesis 1. Plant produces CBGA (cannabigerolic acid)—the "mother" cannabinoid 2. Enzymes convert CBGA into THCA, CBDA, or CBCA 3. Heat converts acidic forms to active forms (CBD, THC, CBC) ## Cannabis and the Law Legal status depends on THC content and jurisdiction. ### European Union - Hemp (<0.2% THC): Generally legal - Marijuana: Illegal in most countries - CBD: Legal in most cases, [novel food](/glossary/novel-food) regulations apply - Medical cannabis: Available in some countries ### United Kingdom - Hemp: Legal from approved varieties - Marijuana: Class B controlled substance - CBD: Legal if <1mg THC per container - Medical cannabis: Legal since 2018 ### United States - Hemp (<0.3% THC): Federally legal since 2018 - Marijuana: Federally illegal, state laws vary - CBD from hemp: Legal federally - Medical/recreational cannabis: State-dependent ## Why This Matters for CBD Users Understanding cannabis helps you: **Make informed purchases:** - Know where CBD comes from - Understand product labels - Recognise quality indicators **Understand legality:** - Hemp-derived = generally legal - THC content matters - Regulations vary by country **Appreciate effects:** - [Full-spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) = whole plant compounds - Entourage effect potential - Why terpenes matter ## Meine Meinung After 12+ years in this industry, I've seen how much confusion surrounds the cannabis plant itself. The biggest misconception I encounter is people thinking CBD and marijuana are the same thing—they're not. Cannabis is simply the plant family, like saying "citrus" for oranges and lemons. Hemp and marijuana are just different varieties bred for different purposes. What fascinates me most is how this single plant produces over 100 different cannabinoids, each with unique properties. I've tested products from cannabis plants with THC levels ranging from 0.01% to 30%+, and the difference in effects is remarkable. The legal distinction at 0.3% THC isn't arbitrary—it's the threshold where psychoactive effects typically begin. The most common question I get is "Will CBD from cannabis get me high?" The answer depends entirely on the specific plant variety and extraction method. This is why understanding the cannabis plant fundamentals matters for making informed choices about CBD products. --- ## Verwandte Studien Research related to this topic: - [What has research over the past two decades revealed about the adverse health ef... (2014)](/research/study/what-has-research-over-the-past-two-decades-revealed-about-t-2014-092604) - Human Trial - [Cannabis for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: What is the patient... (2023)](/research/study/cannabis-for-the-treatment-of-amyotrophic-lateral-sclerosis-2023-3068aa) - Human Trial - [Medical cannabis or cannabinoids for [chronic pain](/conditions/chronic_pain): a clinical practice guideline (2021)](/research/study/medical-cannabis-or-cannabinoids-for-chronic-[pain](/conditions/pain)-a-clinical-2021-9c4515) - Human Trial - [For adults with opioid-refractory [cancer](/conditions/cancer) pain, what are the benefits and harms o... (2023)](/research/study/for-adults-with-opioid-refractory-cancer-pain-what-are-the-b-2023-6cd917) - Human Trial - [Preliminary efficacy and safety of an oromucosal standardized cannabis extract i... (2010)](/research/study/preliminary-efficacy-and-safety-of-an-oromucosal-standardize-2010-d693c9) - Human Trial [Browse all CBD research →](/research) ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### Is cannabis the same as marijuana? Cannabis is the plant genus; marijuana is a term for high-THC cannabis varieties. All marijuana is cannabis, but not all cannabis is marijuana. Hemp is also cannabis but with very low THC. The terms are often confused, but the distinction matters for legality and effects. ### Does all cannabis get you high? No. Only cannabis with significant THC content causes intoxication. Hemp (low-THC cannabis) and CBD products don't produce a "high." The cannabis plant produces over 100 cannabinoids, and only THC is notably intoxicating. CBD from hemp won't cause any high. ### Is CBD from cannabis or hemp? CBD can come from either, but commercial CBD products typically come from hemp because it's legal and can be high in CBD with minimal THC. Chemically, CBD is the same molecule whether it comes from hemp or high-THC cannabis varieties. ### Why is hemp legal but marijuana isn't? The distinction is primarily political and based on THC content. Hemp (under 0.2-0.3% THC) doesn't produce intoxicating effects, so it's treated differently under law. The 2018 US Farm Bill and similar legislation globally legalised hemp agriculture and hemp-derived products including CBD. ### Can you tell hemp and marijuana plants apart? Not reliably by looking. High-CBD hemp and marijuana plants can look identical. The difference is in the chemical composition, which requires laboratory testing to determine. This is why legal hemp operations must test crops to verify THC compliance. ### What part of the cannabis plant does CBD come from? CBD is most concentrated in the flowers (buds) of female cannabis plants, specifically in the trichomes. While leaves and stems contain some cannabinoids, extraction focuses on flowers for efficiency. Seeds contain no significant cannabinoids. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [What is Hemp?](/articles/what-is-hemp) - [Hemp vs Marijuana](/articles/hemp-vs-marijuana) - [What is CBD?](/articles/what-is-cbd) - [What Are Cannabinoids?](/articles/what-are-cannabinoids) - [Cannabis Sativa vs Indica vs Ruderalis](/articles/cannabis-sativa-indica-ruderalis) --- ## Sources 1. Small E. (2015). "Evolution and Classification of Cannabis sativa." *Botanical Review*. 2. Russo EB. (2011). "Taming THC: potential cannabis synergy and phytocannabinoid-terpenoid entourage effects." *British Journal of Pharmacology*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21749363/) 3. Andre CM, et al. (2016). "Cannabis sativa: The Plant of the Thousand and One Molecules." *Frontiers in Plant Science*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26870049/) --- **Medizinischer Haftungsausschluss:** Dieser Artikel dient nur zu Informationszwecken und stellt keine medizinische Beratung dar. CBD is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. Konsultieren Sie einen Arzt, bevor Sie CBD verwenden.
