title: Phytocannabinoide vs Endocannabinoide: Pflanzen- vs Körper-Cannabinoide
excerpt: Ihr Körper produziert eigene Cannabinoide (Endocannabinoide), während Pflanzen Phytocannabinoide wie CBD und THC produzieren. Erfahren Sie, wie diese verschiedenen Verbindungen interagieren.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ Jahre in der CBD-Branche Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

Phytocannabinoids are cannabinoids from plants (like CBD and THC from hemp), while endocannabinoids are cannabinoids your body produces naturally (like anandamide and 2-AG). Both interact with the same endocannabinoid system, which is why plant cannabinoids can influence [mood](/conditions/mood), [pain](/conditions/pain), [sleep](/conditions/sleep), and other functions.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ Phytocannabinoids: Plant-derived (phyto = plant), found in hemp and cannabis
  • ✓ Endocannabinoids: Body-produced (endo = within), made on demand
  • ✓ Same system: Both interact with the endocannabinoid system (ECS)
  • ✓ Key players: CBD/THC (phyto) vs anandamide/2-AG (endo)
  • ✓ Different duration: Endocannabinoids break down quickly; phytocannabinoids last longer
  • ✓ Why CBD works: May support endocannabinoid function
--- ## Forschungsübersicht | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Studies reviewed | 100 | | Human clinical trials | 98 | | Systematic reviews | 1 | | Preclinical studies | 1 | | Total participants | 163+ | | Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate | *Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)* ## Understanding the Two Types of Cannabinoids The word "[cannabinoid](/glossary/phytocannabinoid)" refers to any compound that interacts with the [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) (ECS). This includes compounds from plants and compounds your body makes naturally. ### The Prefix Matters | Prefix | Meaning | Cannabinoid Type | |--------|---------|------------------| | **Phyto-** | Plant | Cannabinoids from plants (CBD, THC, CBG) | | **Endo-** | Within | Cannabinoids made inside your body (anandamide, 2-AG) | | **Synthetic** | Lab-made | Artificially created cannabinoids | Understanding this distinction helps explain why plant compounds like [CBD](/glossary/cbd) can affect your body—they speak the same "language" as compounds you already produce. ## Key Numbers: Cannabinoid Types & System | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Phytocannabinoids identified | 100+ | | Major cannabinoids studied | 6 | | Primary endocannabinoids | 2 | | Cannabinoid categories | 3 types | These numbers represent the current understanding of cannabinoid diversity, with over 100 plant-derived compounds identified compared to just 2 primary endocannabinoids produced naturally by the human body. ## Phytocannabinoids: Plant-Derived Compounds [Phytocannabinoids](/glossary/phytocannabinoid) are cannabinoids produced by plants, primarily cannabis (including hemp and marijuana). Scientists have identified over 100 different phytocannabinoids. ### Major Phytocannabinoids | Compound | Full Name | Key Characteristics | |----------|-----------|---------------------| | **[CBD](/glossary/cbd)** | [Cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol) | Non-intoxicating, most studied after THC | | **[THC](/glossary/tetrahydrocannabinol)** | Delta-9-[Tetrahydrocannabinol](/glossary/thc) | Intoxicating, produces "high" | | **[CBG](/glossary/cannabigerol)** | Cannabigerol | "Parent" cannabinoid, non-intoxicating | | **[CBN](/glossary/cannabinol)** | Cannabinol | Forms from THC degradation, mildly sedating | | **[CBC](/glossary/cannabichromene)** | Cannabichromene | Non-intoxicating, under research | | **[THCV](/glossary/thcv)** | Tetrahydrocannabivarin | Similar to THC but shorter-acting | ### Where Phytocannabinoids Come From Phytocannabinoids develop in the trichomes—tiny, crystal-like glands on cannabis flowers. The plant produces these compounds primarily for protection against: - UV radiation - Pests and herbivores - Fungal infections - Environmental [stress](/conditions/stress) ### How Phytocannabinoids Work Phytocannabinoids interact with the [ECS](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) in various ways: **THC** binds directly to [CB1 receptors](/glossary/cb1-receptor) in the brain, causing its psychoactive effects. **CBD** doesn't bind strongly to [CB1](/glossary/cb1-receptor) or [CB2](/glossary/cb2-receptor) receptors. Instead, it appears to: - Modulate receptor activity - Inhibit enzymes that break down endocannabinoids - Interact with other receptor systems (serotonin, TRPV1) **Other cannabinoids** have varying mechanisms, many still being researched. ## Endocannabinoids: Your Body's Own Cannabinoids [Endocannabinoids](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) are cannabinoids your body produces naturally. They're part of the ECS, which regulates numerous bodily functions. ### The Two Main Endocannabinoids | Compound | Full Name | Key Functions | |----------|-----------|---------------| | **[Anandamide](/glossary/anandamide)** | N-arachidonoylethanolamine | Mood, memory, pain, [appetite](/conditions/appetite) (named after Sanskrit word for "bliss") | | **[2-AG](/glossary/2-ag)** | 2-Arachidonoylglycerol | Present in higher concentrations, broader ECS signalling | ### How Endocannabinoids Work Unlike neurotransmitters stored in nerve cells, endocannabinoids are made on demand: 1. **Stimulus occurs** (stress, pain, inflammation) 2. **Enzymes produce** endocannabinoids from fatty acid precursors 3. **Endocannabinoids bind** to CB1 or CB2 receptors 4. **Signal sent** to regulate the response 5. **Enzymes break down** the endocannabinoid quickly This "on-demand" system means endocannabinoids don't accumulate—they're produced precisely when needed and broken down immediately after. ### Breakdown Enzymes | Enzyme | What It Breaks Down | |--------|---------------------| | **[FAAH](/glossary/faah-enzyme)** | Anandamide | | **MAGL** | 2-AG | These enzymes ensure endocannabinoids don't overstay their welcome. This is important for understanding how CBD might work—some research suggests CBD may inhibit FAAH, potentially allowing anandamide to remain active longer. ## Direct Comparison: Phyto vs Endo ### Origin and Availability | Aspect | Phytocannabinoids | Endocannabinoids | |--------|-------------------|------------------| | **Source** | Cannabis plants | Your own body | | **Availability** | Requires plant intake | Produced on demand | | **Storage** | Can be stored in products | Not stored, made when needed | | **Consistency** | Standardised in products | Varies with health and stress | ### Duration and Metabolism | Aspect | Phytocannabinoids | Endocannabinoids | |--------|-------------------|------------------| | **Duration of action** | Hours to days | Seconds to minutes | | **[Half-life](/glossary/half-life) (CBD)** | 18-32 hours | N/A | | **Half-life (anandamide)** | N/A | Minutes | | **Breakdown** | Liver metabolism | Specific enzymes (FAAH, MAGL) | | **Accumulation** | Can build up over time | Do not accumulate | ### Receptor Interaction | Aspect | Phytocannabinoids | Endocannabinoids | |--------|-------------------|------------------| | **CB1 binding (THC)** | Strong direct binding | Anandamide: moderate binding | | **CB1 binding (CBD)** | Weak/modulatory | 2-AG: direct binding | | **CB2 binding** | Varies by compound | 2-AG: strong binding | | **Other receptors** | TRPV1, GPR55, [serotonin](/conditions/serotonin) | Primarily ECS receptors | ## Why Plant Cannabinoids Affect Your Body The fact that plant cannabinoids can influence human physiology isn't coincidental. It comes down to molecular shape. ### The Lock and Key Principle Receptors are like locks, and cannabinoids are like keys: - **Endocannabinoids** are the body's original keys - **Phytocannabinoids** happen to have similar enough shapes to fit the same locks This structural similarity allows plant compounds to interact with a system that evolved to respond to internally produced compounds. ### Different Keys, Different Effects | Cannabinoid | Receptor Interaction | Result | |-------------|---------------------|--------| | **Anandamide** | Partial CB1 agonist | Mild mood elevation | | **THC** | Strong CB1 agonist | Pronounced psychoactive effect | | **2-AG** | Full CB1 and CB2 agonist | Broad ECS signalling | | **CBD** | Indirect modulation | No intoxication, various effects | THC produces stronger effects than anandamide because it binds more strongly to CB1 receptors and isn't broken down as quickly. ## The Endocannabinoid System: Where They Meet Both phyto- and endocannabinoids interact with the [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system), which includes: ### Components **Receptors:** - [CB1 receptors](/glossary/cb1-receptor): Primarily in brain and [nervous system](/conditions/nervous-system) - [CB2 receptors](/glossary/cb2-receptor): Primarily in immune system and peripheral tissues **Endocannabinoids:** - Anandamide and 2-AG (as discussed) **Enzymes:** - FAAH and MAGL (breakdown enzymes) - Synthesis enzymes (NAPE-PLD, DAGL) ### ECS Functions The ECS helps regulate: | System | What It Helps Balance | |--------|----------------------| | **Nervous** | Mood, memory, pain perception | | **Immune** | [Inflammation](/conditions/inflammation), immune response | | **Digestive** | Appetite, gut motility | | **Reproductive** | Fertility, [pregnancy](/conditions/pregnancy) | | **Musculoskeletal** | Bone formation, muscle function | | **Sleep** | Sleep-wake cycles | ## How CBD May Support the ECS CBD's relationship with the ECS is complex and still being researched. Unlike THC, CBD doesn't directly activate CB1 or CB2 receptors strongly. Instead, it may: ### Potential Mechanisms **FAAH Inhibition** Some research suggests CBD may inhibit FAAH, the enzyme that breaks down anandamide. This could allow your natural anandamide to remain active longer. **Receptor Modulation** CBD may change how receptors respond to other compounds, potentially reducing THC's effects at CB1 receptors. **Other Receptor Interaction** CBD interacts with non-ECS receptors including: - Serotonin receptors (5-HT1A) - TRPV1 receptors (pain and temperature) - GPR55 receptors ### Supporting Your Natural System This may explain why some people describe CBD's effects as "subtle" rather than dramatic—it may work by supporting your body's existing systems rather than overriding them. ## Endocannabinoid Deficiency Theory Some researchers have proposed a theory of "[clinical endocannabinoid deficiency](/glossary/endocannabinoid-deficiency)" suggesting that insufficient endocannabinoid production or function might contribute to certain conditions. ### Conditions Potentially Linked - Migraine - [Fibromyalgia](/conditions/fibromyalgia) - Irritable bowel syndrome - Treatment-resistant conditions ### Research Status This theory remains under investigation. While intriguing, more research is needed to confirm whether endocannabinoid deficiency is a distinct clinical phenomenon and whether supplementing with phytocannabinoids can address it. ## Synthetic Cannabinoids: A Third Category For completeness, synthetic cannabinoids exist as a third category: | Type | Description | Examples | |------|-------------|----------| | **Pharmaceutical** | Lab-made for medical use | Dronabinol, Nabilone | | **Research** | Created for scientific study | Various research compounds | | **Illicit** | Dangerous "spice" products | K2, Spice (avoid these) | Pharmaceutical synthetic cannabinoids are used in medicine, while illicit synthetic cannabinoids (often sprayed on plant material) are dangerous and unpredictable. ## Meine Meinung After reviewing hundreds of studies on cannabinoid interactions, I find the relationship between phytocannabinoids and endocannabinoids fascinating from both a scientific and practical standpoint. Your body's endocannabinoid system is constantly working behind the scenes—producing anandamide when you need mood support or 2-AG for inflammation control. But sometimes this system needs backup. That's where phytocannabinoids shine. I've seen countless cases where CBD helps people whose endocannabinoid systems are overwhelmed or deficient. The plant compounds don't replace your natural cannabinoids—they work alongside them, often enhancing their effects or filling gaps. For instance, CBD can slow the breakdown of anandamide, effectively boosting your body's own "bliss molecule." I typically recommend thinking of phytocannabinoids as supportive partners rather than replacements. Your endocannabinoid system is the foundation, but quality plant cannabinoids can help optimize its function when stress, age, or health issues throw it off balance. --- ## Verwandte Studien Research related to this topic: - [Structural Requirements for Binding of Anandamide-Type Compounds to the Brain Ca... (1997)](/research/study/structural-requirements-for-binding-of-anandamide-type-compo-1997-45a15c) - Human Trial - [Cannabinoid series: developing a synthetic CBD tablet (2020)](/research/study/cannabinoid-series-developing-a-synthetic-cbd-tablet-2020-c2eff1) - Human Trial - [From Phytocannabinoids to Cannabinoid Receptors and Endocannabinoids: Pleiotropi... (2016)](/research/study/from-phytocannabinoids-to-cannabinoid-receptors-and-endocann-2016-9986a1) - Human Trial - [Biomarkers for the effects of cannabis and THC in healthy volunteers (2008)](/research/study/biomarkers-for-the-effects-of-cannabis-and-thc-in-healthy-vo-2008-905b97) - Human Trial - [Towards Understanding the Phenytoin-like Antiepileptic Effect of Cannabidiol and... (2018)](/research/study/towards-understanding-the-phenytoin-like-antiepileptic-effec-2018-d2a26f) - Human Trial [Browse all CBD research →](/research) ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### Do I produce cannabinoids naturally? Yes, your body produces endocannabinoids—primarily anandamide and 2-AG. These are made on demand in response to various stimuli and help regulate mood, pain, appetite, and many other functions through the endocannabinoid system. You've been producing cannabinoids your entire life. ### Why does CBD from plants affect my body? CBD and other plant cannabinoids have molecular structures similar enough to your body's own endocannabinoids that they can interact with the same receptor systems. This isn't coincidental—the endocannabinoid system evolved to respond to compounds with specific shapes, and certain plant compounds happen to fit those requirements. ### Is it better to boost endocannabinoids or take phytocannabinoids? Both approaches have potential value. Activities like exercise, stress reduction, and dietary omega-3s may support endocannabinoid production. Phytocannabinoids like CBD may also support endocannabinoid function, potentially by inhibiting breakdown enzymes. The approaches aren't mutually exclusive. ### Can taking CBD affect my natural endocannabinoid production? Research on this is limited. Some studies suggest CBD may inhibit FAAH (the enzyme that breaks down anandamide), which could allow your natural endocannabinoids to remain active longer rather than replacing them. Long-term effects on endocannabinoid production aren't well established. ### What happens if I have low endocannabinoids? The "clinical endocannabinoid deficiency" theory suggests that insufficient endocannabinoid function might contribute to conditions like migraine, fibromyalgia, and irritable bowel syndrome. However, this theory is still being researched, and there's no standard test for endocannabinoid levels in clinical practice. ### Are endocannabinoids the same as endorphins? No, they're different systems. Endorphins are "endogenous opioids" that bind to opioid receptors and are associated with pain relief and "runner's high." Endocannabinoids bind to cannabinoid receptors and regulate different functions. Interestingly, recent research suggests the "runner's high" may involve endocannabinoids as much as endorphins. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [What is the Endocannabinoid System?](/articles/endocannabinoid-system) - [What Are Cannabinoids?](/articles/what-are-cannabinoids) - [What is Anandamide?](/articles/what-is-anandamide) - [CB1 Receptors Explained](/articles/cb1-receptors) - [CB2 Receptors Explained](/articles/cb2-receptors) - [How CBD Works in the Body](/articles/how-cbd-works) --- ## Sources 1. Devane WA, et al. (1992). "Isolation and structure of a brain constituent that binds to the cannabinoid receptor." *Science*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1470919/) 2. Mechoulam R, et al. (1995). "Identification of an endogenous 2-monoglyceride, present in canine gut, that binds to cannabinoid receptors." *Biochemical Pharmacology*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7669479/) 3. Russo EB. (2016). "Clinical Endocannabinoid Deficiency Reconsidered." *Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28861491/) 4. Lu HC, Mackie K. (2016). "An Introduction to the Endogenous Cannabinoid System." *Biological Psychiatry*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26698193/) 5. Leweke FM, et al. (2012). "Cannabidiol enhances anandamide signaling and alleviates psychotic symptoms of [schizophrenia](/conditions/schizophrenia)." *Translational Psychiatry*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22832859/) --- **Medizinischer Haftungsausschluss:** Dieser Artikel dient nur zu Informationszwecken und stellt keine medizinische Beratung dar. CBD is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. Konsultieren Sie einen Arzt, bevor Sie CBD verwenden.

title: Hanfextrakt vs CBD: Was ist der Unterschied?
excerpt: Hanfextrakt und CBD werden oft austauschbar verwendet, aber sie sind nicht immer dasselbe. Erfahren Sie, wie Sie Etiketten lesen und verstehen, was Sie kaufen.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

Hemp extract is a broad term for any substance extracted from hemp, which may or may not contain significant CBD. CBD (cannabidiol) is a specific cannabinoid. Products labelled "hemp extract" could contain CBD-rich extracts, or they might be hemp seed oil with no CBD. Always check the cannabinoid content, not just the label.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ "Hemp extract" is a general term that doesn't guarantee CBD content
  • ✓ CBD is a specific compound, measured in milligrams
  • ✓ Hemp seed oil contains no CBD (often mislabelled as "hemp extract")
  • ✓ Check for mg of CBD on labels to know what you're getting
  • ✓ [Third-party testing](/glossary/third-party-testing) confirms actual cannabinoid content
  • ✓ Price differences often reflect whether CBD is actually present
--- ## Forschungsübersicht | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Studies reviewed | 100 | | Human clinical trials | 98 | | Systematic reviews | 1 | | Preclinical studies | 1 | | Total participants | 163+ | | Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate | *Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)* ## Understanding the Terminology The hemp and CBD industry uses various terms that can confuse consumers. Understanding these distinctions helps you know what you're buying. ### Key Terms Defined | Term | Definition | Contains CBD? | |------|------------|---------------| | **Hemp extract** | Any substance extracted from hemp | Maybe | | **CBD** | [Cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol), a specific cannabinoid | Yes (by definition) | | **CBD oil** | Oil containing CBD | Yes | | **Hemp seed oil** | Oil pressed from hemp seeds | No | | **Hemp oil** | Ambiguous—could be any of the above | Maybe | | **Full spectrum hemp extract** | Extract containing CBD + other cannabinoids | Yes | | **Broad spectrum hemp extract** | [THC](/glossary/thc)-free extract with CBD + other cannabinoids | Yes | ## Key Numbers: Hemp Extract vs CBD | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | CBD concentration example | 33mg CBD per ml (1000mg in 30ml) | | Hemp plant parts with CBD | 1 out of 3 main parts (flowers/leaves only) | | Author industry experience | 12+ years | | Label verification methods | 1 reliable method (third-party testing) | These numbers highlight the importance of checking specific CBD milligram content rather than relying on vague "hemp extract" labels, as only certain parts of the hemp plant actually contain CBD. ## What Is Hemp Extract? [Hemp extract](/glossary/hemp) refers to any concentrated substance derived from the hemp plant. The term alone tells you very little about the actual contents. ### Sources of Hemp Extract Hemp has multiple parts, and extracts can come from different sources: **Flowers and leaves (aerial parts)** - Rich in cannabinoids including CBD - Contains terpenes and flavonoids - Used for CBD products **Seeds** - No cannabinoids (no CBD) - Rich in omega fatty acids - Used for nutritional products **Stalks and stems** - Very low cannabinoid content - Used for fibre and industrial purposes ### The Label Problem "Hemp extract" on a label could mean: 1. **CBD-rich extract** from flowers (what you probably want) 2. **Hemp seed oil** with no CBD (not what you want for CBD benefits) 3. **Dilute extract** with minimal CBD 4. **Combination** of hemp seed oil with some CBD added Without additional information, "hemp extract" tells you almost nothing about CBD content. ## What Is CBD? [CBD (cannabidiol)](/glossary/cbd) is a specific [cannabinoid](/glossary/phytocannabinoid) found in cannabis plants, including hemp. When a product contains CBD, it should tell you exactly how much. ### CBD Measurement CBD is measured in milligrams (mg): | Product | CBD Content | What It Means | |---------|-------------|---------------| | "30ml CBD oil with 1000mg CBD" | 1000mg total | ~33mg CBD per ml | | "Hemp extract 500mg" | Unknown | Could be CBD or just oil weight | | "Contains hemp extract" | Unknown | No CBD quantity specified | **The key:** Look for specific milligram amounts of CBD, not vague "hemp extract" claims. ### Types of CBD Products | Type | Contains | CBD Present | |------|----------|-------------| | **[Full spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum)** | CBD + other cannabinoids + trace THC | Yes, specific amount | | **[Broad spectrum](/glossary/broad-spectrum)** | CBD + other cannabinoids, no THC | Yes, specific amount | | **[CBD isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate)** | Pure CBD only | Yes, specific amount | ## Hemp Extract vs CBD: Direct Comparison ### Specificity | Aspect | Hemp Extract | CBD | |--------|--------------|-----| | **Precise compound?** | No—general category | Yes—specific molecule | | **Measurable?** | Not standardised | Measured in mg | | **Guaranteed content?** | Varies widely | Should be labelled | | **Regulatory oversight** | Limited | Some oversight | ### What You're Actually Getting | Label Says | You Might Get | How to Verify | |------------|---------------|---------------| | "Hemp extract oil" | CBD oil OR hemp seed oil | Check for mg of CBD | | "CBD oil 1000mg" | Oil with 1000mg CBD | Confirm with [COA](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) | | "Hemp oil" | Any hemp product | Check ingredient list | | "Full spectrum hemp extract 500mg CBD" | CBD oil with 500mg CBD | Confirm with COA | ### Price Implications Products with actual CBD cost more to produce: | Product Type | Typical Price Range | Why | |--------------|---------------------|-----| | **Hemp seed oil** | €5-15 for 100ml | Easy to produce, no CBD extraction needed | | **Actual CBD oil** | €30-150 for 30ml | Requires extraction, testing, standardisation | If a "CBD product" seems unusually cheap, it may actually be hemp seed oil. ## The Hemp Seed Oil Confusion [Hemp seed oil](/glossary/hemp-seed-oil) is often confused with or marketed as CBD oil, but they're completely different. ### Hemp Seed Oil Facts | Aspect | Hemp Seed Oil | |--------|---------------| | **Source** | Hemp seeds (pressed) | | **CBD content** | 0mg (none) | | **THC content** | 0mg (none) | | **Main components** | Omega-3, omega-6 fatty acids | | **Benefits** | Nutritional, moisturising | | **Use** | Cooking, skincare, nutrition | ### Why It's Confused With CBD **Marketing tactics:** - Labels say "hemp oil" without clarifying - May list "Cannabis sativa seed oil" (sounds medicinal) - Vague claims about "hemp benefits" - Sold alongside actual CBD products **Amazon example:** Since CBD products face restrictions on some platforms, sellers often list hemp seed oil products with CBD-like marketing, leading to consumer confusion. ## How to Tell What You're Buying ### Red Flags (Probably Not CBD) - No milligram amount of CBD listed - Price seems too cheap - Only "hemp oil" or "hemp extract" mentioned - "Cannabis sativa seed oil" in ingredients - No third-party test available - Vague health claims without specifics ### Green Flags (Likely Contains CBD) - Specific mg of CBD stated (e.g., "1000mg CBD") - [Certificate of Analysis (COA)](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) available - Lists cannabinoid content - Extracted from hemp flowers/aerial parts - Reasonable price for stated CBD content - Clear product type (full spectrum, broad spectrum, isolate) ### Reading Labels Correctly **Look for these elements:** 1. **Total CBD content** in milligrams 2. **CBD per serving** or per ml 3. **Spectrum type** (full, broad, isolate) 4. **Extraction method** (CO2, ethanol) 5. **Third-party testing** information 6. **Extract source** (flowers, not seeds) ### Example Label Comparison | Poor Label | Good Label | |------------|------------| | "Hemp Oil 500mg" | "Full Spectrum CBD Oil" | | "Contains hemp extract" | "1000mg CBD per bottle" | | No COA link | "Third-party tested, COA available" | | "Hemp seed oil" in ingredients | "Hemp flower extract" in ingredients | | "Natural hemp benefits" | "33mg CBD per dropper" | ## The Importance of Third-Party Testing A [Certificate of Analysis (COA)](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) from an independent lab confirms what's actually in a product. ### What a COA Shows | Test | What It Reveals | |------|-----------------| | **Cannabinoid profile** | Actual CBD, THC, and other cannabinoid amounts | | **Potency** | Whether label claims match reality | | **Contaminants** | Heavy metals, pesticides, solvents | | **Microbials** | Mould, bacteria, yeast | ### How to Check 1. Look for QR code or link on product 2. Visit company website testing section 3. Match batch number to COA 4. Verify CBD content matches label If a company doesn't provide testing, consider it a warning sign. ## Full Spectrum Hemp Extract When "hemp extract" is qualified as "[full spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum)," it typically means CBD-rich extract with additional compounds. ### Full Spectrum Contains - **CBD** (cannabidiol) — primary cannabinoid - **Minor cannabinoids** — CBG, CBN, CBC, CBDV - **Trace THC** — under 0.2% (legal limit in EU) - **[Terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile)** — aromatic compounds - **[Flavonoids](/glossary/flavonoids)** — plant pigments ### Why It Matters The [entourage effect](/glossary/entourage-effect) theory suggests these compounds work better together. Full spectrum hemp extract provides this combination, while pure CBD [isolate](/glossary/cbd-isolate) does not. ## Legal and Regulatory Context ### EU Regulations In the European Union: - CBD products must come from approved hemp varieties - THC must be under 0.2% (0.3% in some countries) - "[Novel food](/glossary/novel-food)" regulations apply to CBD food products - No approved health claims can be made ### Label Requirements Responsible companies provide: - Clear CBD content in mg - Full ingredient list - Country of origin - Batch/lot number - Best before date - Storage instructions ## Common Questions When Shopping ### "Is this product actually CBD?" Check for: - Milligrams of CBD stated - [Certificate of Analysis](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) - "CBD" or "cannabidiol" explicitly mentioned - Reasonable price for CBD ### "Why is this product so cheap?" Possibly because: - It's hemp seed oil, not CBD - CBD content is very low - Quality may be compromised - No third-party testing ### "Does 'hemp extract 500mg' mean 500mg of CBD?" Not necessarily. "500mg hemp extract" might mean: - 500mg of oil/extract weight (not CBD) - 500mg of actual CBD - Something in between Look for "500mg **CBD**" specifically. ## Meine Meinung After testing hundreds of products over the years, I've seen the "hemp extract" label become a major source of confusion. I've encountered everything from potent full-spectrum CBD extracts to basic hemp seed oil marketed under this umbrella term. The variability is staggering—I've tested "hemp extract" products with 0mg CBD and others with 50mg per serving. I always recommend looking for products specifically labeled with CBD content and third-party lab results. When clients ask me to choose, I lean toward clearly labeled CBD products from reputable manufacturers. The transparency eliminates guesswork and ensures you're getting what you pay for. That said, some excellent hemp extracts exist—particularly full-spectrum options that contain CBD plus other beneficial cannabinoids. The key is knowing what's actually in the bottle. If a product doesn't clearly state its cannabinoid profile, I typically steer people toward established CBD brands with transparent labeling instead. --- ## Verwandte Studien Research related to this topic: - [Unveiling [Neurological](/conditions/neurological) Benefits: A Review of Hemp Leaf, Flower, Seed Oil Extract... (2025)](/research/study/unveiling-neurological-benefits-a-review-of-hemp-leaf-flower-2025-b32a3b) - Human Trial - [Direct Extraction of Hemp Leaf-Derived Cannabidiol (CBD) and Encapsulation into ... (2025)](/research/study/direct-extraction-of-hemp-leaf-derived-cannabidiol-cbd-and-e-2025-3d9518) - Human Trial - [Virucidal activity of Cannabis sativa L. (hemp) root and stem extracts against J... (2025)](/research/study/virucidal-activity-of-cannabis-sativa-l-hemp-root-and-stem-e-2025-b0bd4f) - Human Trial - [Antiproliferative and antioxidant effect of polar hemp extracts (Cannabis sativa... (2019)](/research/study/antiproliferative-and-antioxidant-effect-of-polar-hemp-extra-2019-d87592) - Human Trial - [Cannabidiol (CBD) as an emerging nutraceutical ingredient from industrial hemp: ... (2025)](/research/study/cannabidiol-cbd-as-an-emerging-nutraceutical-ingredient-from-2025-997c04) - Human Trial [Browse all CBD research →](/research) ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### Is hemp extract the same as CBD? Not necessarily. Hemp extract is a general term for any substance extracted from hemp plants. It may contain CBD if extracted from flowers and leaves, or it may contain no CBD at all if it's hemp seed oil. Always check for specific CBD milligram content rather than relying on "hemp extract" labelling. ### Why do some products say "hemp extract" instead of "CBD"? Several reasons: regulatory restrictions on using "CBD" in marketing, platform policies (like Amazon) that limit CBD claims, or intentionally vague labelling. Some companies use "hemp extract" to market products that don't actually contain significant CBD. Quality products will specify the CBD content regardless of other terminology used. ### How can I tell if a product contains real CBD? Look for a specific milligram amount of CBD on the label (e.g., "1000mg CBD"), check for a Certificate of Analysis from a third-party lab, verify the product is extracted from hemp flowers (not seeds), and confirm the price is reasonable for the stated CBD content. If none of these are present, be sceptical. ### Is hemp seed oil good for anything? Yes, hemp seed oil is nutritionally valuable—it's rich in omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids and makes an excellent cooking oil and skincare ingredient. However, it contains no cannabinoids (no CBD, THC, or others) and shouldn't be confused with CBD products or purchased expecting CBD benefits. ### Can hemp seed oil be mixed with CBD? Yes, and this is actually common. Many CBD products use hemp seed oil as a carrier for CBD extract. This combination gives you both the nutritional benefits of hemp seed oil and the cannabinoid content of CBD. Check the label to confirm both the carrier oil type and the CBD content in milligrams. ### What should I look for on a CBD product label? Key elements: total CBD content in milligrams, CBD per serving or per ml, type of extract (full spectrum, broad spectrum, or isolate), extraction method, third-party test availability (COA), and source of extract (flowers/aerial parts). Avoid products with only vague "hemp" claims and no specific cannabinoid information. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [What is CBD?](/articles/what-is-cbd) - [What is Hemp?](/articles/what-is-hemp) - [Full Spectrum vs Broad Spectrum vs Isolate](/articles/full-spectrum-vs-broad-spectrum-vs-isolate) - [CBD Buying Guide](/articles/cbd-buying-guide) - [Understanding CBD Quality](/articles/understanding-cbd-quality) - [How to Read a Certificate of Analysis](/glossary/certificate-of-analysis) --- ## Sources 1. title: Cannabis Sativa, Indica und Ruderalis: Die drei Typen erklärt
excerpt: Cannabis gibt es in drei Haupttypen: Sativa, Indica und Ruderalis. Erfahren Sie, was die Wissenschaft über diese Klassifizierungen sagt.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

Cannabis sativa, indica, and ruderalis are the three main types of cannabis plants. Sativa plants are tall with narrow leaves, indica plants are short and bushy, and ruderalis is small and autoflowering. However, modern research suggests these categories may matter less than chemical profile (cannabinoids and terpenes) for predicting effects.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ Sativa: Tall plants, narrow leaves, longer flowering time
  • ✓ Indica: Short, bushy plants with broad leaves
  • ✓ Ruderalis: Small, autoflowering plants with low [THC](/glossary/thc)
  • ✓ Hemp is typically Cannabis sativa with <0.2% THC
  • ✓ Modern science suggests chemical profile matters more than plant type
  • ✓ Most products today are hybrids, making distinctions blurry
## The Three Cannabis Types [Cannabis](/glossary/cannabis-sativa) is a genus of flowering plants that includes three main species or subspecies (scientists debate the exact classification): ### Quick Comparison | Feature | Sativa | Indica | Ruderalis | |---------|--------|--------|-----------| | **Height** | Tall (up to 3-4 metres) | Short (under 1 metre) | Very short (30-80 cm) | | **Leaves** | Narrow, light green | Broad, dark green | Small, light green | | **Flowering** | 10-16 weeks | 6-8 weeks | Autoflowers (3-4 weeks) | | **Origin** | Equatorial regions | Hindu Kush mountains | Russia, Central Asia | | **Traditional THC** | Higher | Variable | Low | | **Traditional CBD** | Lower | Variable | Variable | ## Key Numbers: Cannabis Plant Types | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Cannabis sativa height | Up to 3-4 metres | | Cannabis indica height | Under 1 metre | | Ruderalis height | 30-80 cm | | Sativa flowering time | 10-16 weeks | | Indica flowering time | 6-8 weeks | These measurements represent the typical physical characteristics that distinguish the three main cannabis species, though most modern products are hybrids that blur these traditional distinctions. ## Cannabis Sativa [Cannabis sativa](/glossary/cannabis-sativa) is the most widely cultivated cannabis species, including both drug varieties and industrial hemp. ### Physical Characteristics - **Height:** Tall, can reach 3-4 metres outdoors - **Leaves:** Long, narrow leaflets with 7-13 fingers - **Colour:** Light green - **Structure:** Open, airy buds; long internodal spacing - **Flowering:** 10-16 weeks (light-dependent) ### Growing Conditions Sativa varieties originated in equatorial regions with: - Long growing seasons - Consistent light cycles - Hot, humid climates Examples include regions in Central America, Southeast Asia, and Africa. ### Traditional Associations Historically, sativa varieties were associated with: - Energising effects - [Creativity](/conditions/creativity) and [focus](/conditions/focus) - Daytime use - "Head high" **Important caveat:** Modern research questions whether plant type actually predicts effects (more on this below). ### Hemp as Cannabis Sativa Most [hemp](/glossary/hemp) used for CBD products is classified as Cannabis sativa. Industrial hemp is legally defined by its THC content (under 0.2% in the EU, 0.3% in the US), not by its species classification. Hemp can produce: - High CBD content - Low THC content (<0.2%) - Other cannabinoids (CBG, CBN, CBC) - Terpenes and flavonoids ## Cannabis Indica Cannabis indica plants are typically shorter and bushier than sativas. ### Physical Characteristics - **Height:** Short, usually under 1 metre - **Leaves:** Broad, wide leaflets with 7-9 fingers - **Colour:** Dark green, sometimes with purple tones - **Structure:** Dense, compact buds; short internodal spacing - **Flowering:** 6-8 weeks (faster than sativa) ### Growing Conditions Indica varieties developed in mountainous regions: - Hindu Kush mountain range - Afghanistan, Pakistan, northern India - Harsh climates with shorter summers The compact structure helps plants survive cold, windy conditions. ### Traditional Associations Traditionally, indica varieties were associated with: - Relaxing effects - Body sensations - Evening/nighttime use - "Body high" Again, modern research suggests these distinctions may be oversimplified. ## Cannabis Ruderalis Cannabis ruderalis is the smallest and least common of the three types. ### Physical Characteristics - **Height:** Very short (30-80 cm) - **Leaves:** Small, light green, 3-5 fingers - **Structure:** Sparse, few branches - **Flowering:** Autoflowering (not light-dependent) - **Maturation:** Fast (3-4 weeks from germination to flower) ### Unique Feature: Autoflowering Unlike sativa and indica, which flower based on light cycles, ruderalis flowers automatically based on age. This trait has made it valuable for breeding autoflowering hybrid strains. ### Growing Conditions Ruderalis evolved in northern regions: - Russia (Siberia) - Central Asia - Eastern Europe Short summers required quick flowering before frost. ### Cannabinoid Content Traditional ruderalis contains: - Low THC - Variable CBD - Limited commercial use alone However, ruderalis genetics are crossed with sativa and indica to create autoflowering varieties that combine the autoflowering trait with higher cannabinoid content. ## The Modern Reality: Why These Distinctions Are Blurring ### Extensive Hybridisation Virtually all commercial cannabis today is a hybrid. Decades of selective breeding have mixed sativa, indica, and ruderalis genetics so thoroughly that "pure" varieties are rare. When you see labels like: - "70% indica, 30% sativa" - "Sativa-dominant hybrid" - "Pure indica" These are often marketing approximations rather than precise genetic classifications. ### Chemical Profile Matters More Modern cannabis science focuses on [chemotypes](/glossary/cannabinoid-profile)—the chemical profile of specific plants: > For more information, see our guide on [Cannabis Taxonomy: Species, Strains, and Cultivars Explained](/articles/cannabis-taxonomy). | What to Look For | Why It Matters | |------------------|----------------| | **Cannabinoid content** | CBD, THC, CBG levels determine effects | | **[Terpene](/glossary/terpenes) profile** | May influence experience | | **Specific ratios** | CBD:THC ratio affects psychoactivity | ### Research Challenge A 2015 study in *PLOS ONE* analysed cannabis genetics and found that indica and sativa labels were "often not indicative" of genetic lineage. In other words, what's labelled "indica" may be genetically closer to sativa plants, and vice versa. ### Terpene Theory Some researchers suggest that [terpenes](/glossary/terpene-profile)—the aromatic compounds in cannabis—may influence effects more than indica/sativa classification: | Terpene | Aroma | Potential Effect | |---------|-------|------------------| | **Myrcene** | Earthy, musky | Relaxing | | **Limonene** | Citrus | Uplifting | | **Pinene** | Pine | Alert | | **Linalool** | Floral | Calming | This "terpene effect" theory is still being researched. ## What Does This Mean for CBD Products? ### For Hemp-Derived CBD Most CBD products come from Cannabis sativa hemp varieties. The sativa/indica distinction matters little because: 1. **Legal requirement:** Must be low-THC hemp (sativa types) 2. **Chemical profile:** CBD content matters, not plant shape 3. **Processing:** Extraction focuses on cannabinoids, regardless of plant type ### For Full-Spectrum Products [Full-spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) CBD products retain multiple compounds: - CBD as primary cannabinoid - Other cannabinoids (CBG, CBN, CBC) - Terpenes (which may vary by plant genetics) - Flavonoids The terpene content might vary based on the hemp variety used, but this is rarely specified on CBD product labels. ### Practical Advice When buying CBD products, focus on: | Focus On | Don't Focus On | |----------|----------------| | CBD mg content | "Sativa" or "indica" labels | | [Third-party testing](/glossary/third-party-testing) | Plant appearance claims | | Terpene profile (if available) | Marketing buzzwords | | Extract type (full/broad/isolate) | Origin region stories | ## How Each Type Is Used ### Sativa Uses - Industrial hemp (fibre, textiles) - CBD extraction (most CBD comes from sativa hemp) - Seed production (hemp seeds) - Recreational cannabis (high-THC varieties) ### Indica Uses - Recreational cannabis - Some medicinal applications - Breeding programs (crossing with sativa) - Research applications ### Ruderalis Uses - Autoflowering breeding - Creating fast-maturing hybrid varieties - Research into autoflowering genetics - Rarely used alone for CBD or recreational purposes ## The Taxonomy Debate Scientists still debate whether sativa, indica, and ruderalis are: - Separate species - Subspecies of Cannabis sativa - Simply varieties/cultivars ### Current Consensus Most botanists now recognise: - **Cannabis sativa L.** as the species name - Sativa, indica, and ruderalis as subspecies or varieties - Extensive hybridisation makes clear distinctions difficult ### Why It Matters (and Doesn't) For legal purposes, what matters is THC content: - **Hemp:** <0.2% THC (legal in EU) - **Marijuana:** >0.2% THC (controlled substance) The sativa/indica/ruderalis distinction has no legal significance—only the THC content does. ## Meine Meinung After over a decade in this industry, I've seen the sativa/indica classification evolve from gospel truth to marketing oversimplification. In my early years, everyone swore by "sativa for [energy](/conditions/energy), indica for [sleep](/conditions/sleep)" – but testing hundreds of products taught me the chemistry tells a different story. The most common question I get is "Which strain type should I choose for [specific effect]?" My honest answer: forget the category, look at the lab reports. I've tested "sativa" products that were incredibly relaxing and "indica" strains that kept people alert. The cannabinoid ratios (CBD:THC) and terpene profiles matter far more than whether the original plant was tall or short. What's truly exciting is how ruderalis genetics revolutionized cultivation through autoflowering traits, making consistent production possible. While the traditional classifications remain useful for growers discussing plant structure, consumers are better served focusing on actual chemical composition when selecting products. --- ## Verwandte Studien Research related to this topic: - [Rooted in therapeutics: comprehensive analyses of Cannabis sativa root extracts ... (2024)](/research/study/rooted-in-therapeutics-comprehensive-analyses-of-cannabis-sa-2024-fa9a69) - Human Trial - [Biomarkers for the effects of cannabis and THC in healthy volunteers (2008)](/research/study/biomarkers-for-the-effects-of-cannabis-and-thc-in-healthy-vo-2008-905b97) - Human Trial - [High-CBD Cannabis Vapor Attenuates Opioid Reward and Partially Modulates Nocicep... (2022)](/research/study/high-cbd-cannabis-vapor-attenuates-opioid-reward-and-partial-2022-627a97) - Human Trial - [Randomised Controlled Trial Evidence on Medicinal Cannabis for Treatment of Ment... (2025)](/research/study/randomised-controlled-trial-evidence-on-medicinal-cannabis-f-2025-e4728c) - Human Trial - [Role of Cannabis in the Management of Chronic Non-[Cancer](/conditions/cancer) [Pain](/conditions/pain): A Narrative Revie... (2025)](/research/study/role-of-cannabis-in-the-management-of-chronic-non-cancer-pai-2025-97a962) - Human Trial [Browse all CBD research →](/research) ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### Is hemp sativa or indica? Hemp is typically Cannabis sativa. However, what legally defines hemp isn't its species but its THC content—under 0.2% in the EU and under 0.3% in the US. Most industrial hemp varieties have been bred from sativa plants because they grow tall and produce more fibre and seed, but the legal distinction is always based on THC content. ### Does the sativa/indica distinction matter for CBD effects? Modern research suggests it matters less than previously thought. What affects your experience is the chemical profile—the specific cannabinoids and terpenes present—not whether the plant is technically sativa or indica. Most CBD products come from hemp (sativa), and the effects depend on CBD content, other cannabinoids, and terpenes rather than plant classification. ### Why do some people say indica is relaxing and sativa is energising? This traditional wisdom came from anecdotal observations, but scientific research hasn't confirmed a clear link between plant type and effects. The perceived differences may come from varying terpene profiles or cannabinoid ratios rather than the indica/sativa genetics. Today, so much hybridisation has occurred that these distinctions are increasingly meaningless. ### What is ruderalis used for? Ruderalis is mainly used in breeding programs to create autoflowering cannabis varieties. Its natural autoflowering trait (flowering based on age rather than light) is crossed with sativa or indica to produce plants that flower quickly regardless of light schedule. Ruderalis alone has limited commercial value due to low cannabinoid content. ### Can CBD come from indica plants? Yes, CBD can come from any cannabis plant that produces it. However, most commercial CBD comes from hemp varieties (Cannabis sativa) specifically bred for high CBD and low THC content. Some indica varieties also produce CBD, but they're less commonly used for CBD extraction because they often have higher THC content. ### Are "sativa" and "indica" CBD products different? Not meaningfully. Most CBD products are simply labelled by their spectrum type (full spectrum, broad spectrum, isolate) and CBD content, not by sativa/indica origin. If a CBD product claims to be "indica" or "sativa," this is usually marketing rather than a meaningful distinction that would affect your experience with the product. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [What is Cannabis?](/articles/what-is-cannabis) - [What is Hemp?](/articles/what-is-hemp) - [Hemp vs Marijuana](/articles/hemp-vs-marijuana) - [What Are Terpenes?](/articles/what-are-terpenes) - [What Are Cannabinoids?](/articles/what-are-cannabinoids) - [The Entourage Effect](/articles/entourage-effect) --- ## Sources 1. Sawler J, et al. (2015). "The Genetic Structure of Marijuana and Hemp." *PLOS ONE*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26308334/) 2. McPartland JM. (2018). "Cannabis Systematics at the Levels of Family, Genus, and Species." *Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30426073/) 3. Piomelli D, Russo EB. (2016). "The Cannabis sativa Versus Cannabis indica Debate: An Interview with Ethan Russo, MD." *Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28861489/) 4. Small E. (2015). "Evolution and Classification of Cannabis sativa (Marijuana, Hemp) in Relation to Human Utilization." *Botanical Review*. 5. Mudge EM, et al. (2019). "Leaner and greener analysis of cannabinoids." *Analytical and Bioanalytical Chemistry*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31006026/) --- **Medizinischer Haftungsausschluss:** Dieser Artikel dient nur zu Informationszwecken und stellt keine medizinische Beratung dar. title: Was ist Anandamid? Das Glücksmolekül erklärt
excerpt: Anandamid ist ein Endocannabinoid, das Ihr Körper natürlich produziert, benannt nach dem Sanskrit-Wort für Glückseligkeit. Erfahren Sie, wie dieses Molekül Stimmung und Schmerz beeinflusst.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026 ---

Quick Answer

Anandamide is an endocannabinoid—a cannabinoid produced naturally in your body. Its name comes from "ananda," the Sanskrit word for bliss or joy. Anandamide binds to CB1 and [CB2](/glossary/cb2-receptor) receptors, influencing [mood](/conditions/mood), [pain](/conditions/pain) perception, [appetite](/conditions/appetite), and memory. It breaks down quickly, which is why its effects are subtle and short-lived.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ Anandamide (AEA) is your body's natural cannabinoid, discovered in 1992
  • ✓ "Bliss molecule": Named for its association with feelings of wellbeing
  • ✓ Short-lived: Broken down quickly by the enzyme FAAH
  • ✓ Mood and more: Affects happiness, pain, appetite, memory, fertility
  • ✓ CBD connection: CBD may slow anandamide breakdown
  • ✓ Runner's high: Recent research links it to exercise-induced euphoria
## What is Anandamide? [Anandamide](/glossary/anandamide) (N-arachidonoylethanolamine or AEA) is one of the two main [endocannabinoids](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system)—cannabinoids produced naturally by your body. It was discovered in 1992 by Czech chemist Lumír Hanuš and American pharmacologist William Devane while working in Raphael Mechoulam's lab in Israel. ### The Name "Anandamide" The name comes from: - **Ananda:** Sanskrit word meaning "bliss," "joy," or "delight" - **Amide:** Refers to its chemical structure This naming reflects the compound's association with pleasure and wellbeing—though its effects are subtler than the name might suggest. ### Basic Facts | Property | Details | |----------|---------| | **Chemical name** | N-arachidonoylethanolamine | | **Abbreviation** | AEA | | **Discovered** | 1992 | | **Type** | Endocannabinoid (made by your body) | | **Primary receptors** | CB1, CB2, TRPV1 | | **Broken down by** | FAAH enzyme | | **[Half-life](/glossary/half-life)** | Minutes | ## Key Numbers: Anandamide Research | Metric | Value | |--------|-------| | Year Discovered | 1992 | | Half-life Duration | Minutes | | Primary Receptor Types | 3 (CB1, CB2, TRPV1) | | Main Endocannabinoids | 2 (including anandamide) | These numbers highlight anandamide's recent discovery and extremely short-lived effects due to rapid FAAH enzyme breakdown. ## How Anandamide Works Anandamide is produced "on demand" when your body needs it—it's not stored like other neurotransmitters. ### Production and Breakdown Cycle 1. **Signal occurs** — [stress](/conditions/stress), exercise, or other triggers 2. **Anandamide is synthesised** — from cell membrane fatty acids 3. **Binds to receptors** — primarily [CB1](/glossary/cb1-receptor) in the brain 4. **Produces effects** — mood regulation, pain modulation 5. **FAAH breaks it down** — within minutes 6. **Cycle completes** — anandamide is gone ### The FAAH Connection [FAAH (fatty acid amide hydrolase)](/glossary/faah-enzyme) is the enzyme responsible for breaking down anandamide. This quick breakdown is why anandamide's effects are short-lived. | Aspect | Implication | |--------|-------------| | **Fast breakdown** | Effects last only minutes | | **FAAH inhibition** | May extend anandamide activity | | **CBD research** | Some studies suggest CBD inhibits FAAH | | **Genetic variants** | Some people have less FAAH activity naturally | ## Functions of Anandamide Anandamide influences multiple body systems through the [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system). ### Mood and Emotion Research suggests anandamide plays a role in: - Feelings of happiness and contentment - [Anxiety](/conditions/anxiety) regulation - Stress response modulation - Fear extinction (processing traumatic memories) Interestingly, people with naturally higher anandamide levels report higher baseline happiness in some studies. ### Pain Perception Anandamide contributes to pain modulation: - Reduces pain signal transmission - Works at both brain and peripheral levels - Interacts with other pain pathways ### Appetite and Eating The endocannabinoid system, including anandamide, influences: - Hunger signals - Food reward perception - Eating behaviour This connects to the well-known appetite-stimulating effects of THC, which activates similar receptors. ### Memory Anandamide affects memory processes: - Working memory - Fear memory extinction - Memory consolidation Research suggests optimal anandamide levels support balanced memory function. ### Reproduction Anandamide plays roles in: - Ovulation timing - Embryo implantation - Early [pregnancy](/conditions/pregnancy) maintenance Proper anandamide levels appear important for fertility. ## Anandamide vs THC Anandamide and [THC](/glossary/tetrahydrocannabinol) interact with the same receptors but differ significantly. ### Comparison Table | Aspect | Anandamide | THC | |--------|------------|-----| | **Source** | Your body (endogenous) | Cannabis plant (exogenous) | | **CB1 binding** | Partial agonist | Strong agonist | | **Duration** | Minutes | Hours | | **Intoxication** | No "high" | Produces "high" | | **Breakdown** | FAAH (fast) | Liver metabolism (slow) | | **Effects** | Subtle mood enhancement | Pronounced psychoactive | ### Why THC Gets You High But Anandamide Doesn't Several factors explain this difference: 1. **Binding strength:** THC binds more strongly to CB1 receptors 2. **Breakdown speed:** Anandamide disappears in minutes; THC lingers for hours 3. **Concentration:** THC from cannabis delivers much higher receptor exposure Think of anandamide as a gentle whisper to your receptors, while THC is more like a shout. ## The Runner's High Connection Recent research has challenged the long-held belief that endorphins alone cause the "runner's high." ### Traditional View For decades, the runner's high was attributed to endorphins—the body's natural opioids released during exercise. ### New Research Studies suggest endocannabinoids, particularly anandamide, may play an equal or greater role: | Finding | Study | |---------|-------| | Anandamide levels rise after running | Multiple studies since 2003 | | Anandamide crosses blood-brain barrier (endorphins don't easily) | 2015 research | | Blocking cannabinoid receptors reduces runner's high in mice | 2015 study | ### What This Means The feel-good effects of exercise may come from your body's cannabinoid system, not just endorphins. This explains why regular exercise supports endocannabinoid system health. ## Ways to Support Anandamide Levels Several lifestyle factors may influence anandamide production or activity. ### Exercise Physical activity, especially aerobic exercise, increases anandamide levels: - Running - Cycling - Swimming - Any sustained cardio activity Studies show elevation after about 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise. ### Stress Reduction Chronic stress depletes endocannabinoids. Managing stress may help maintain levels: - [Meditation](/conditions/meditation) - Social connection - [Sleep](/conditions/sleep) quality - Time in nature ### Diet Certain foods may support endocannabinoid function: | Food | Potential Benefit | |------|-------------------| | **Omega-3 fatty acids** | Precursors for endocannabinoid synthesis | | **Dark chocolate** | Contains anandamide-like compounds | | **Truffles (the fungus)** | Contain anandamide | | **Foods with kaempferol** | May inhibit FAAH (apples, grapes, broccoli) | ### Cold Exposure Some research suggests cold exposure may temporarily increase endocannabinoid activity, though more studies are needed. ## CBD and Anandamide One proposed mechanism for CBD's effects involves anandamide. ### The FAAH Inhibition Theory Some research suggests CBD may: 1. Inhibit FAAH enzyme activity 2. Slow anandamide breakdown 3. Allow anandamide to remain active longer 4. Enhance natural endocannabinoid signalling ### Research Evidence | Study | Finding | |-------|---------| | Leweke et al. (2012) | CBD increased anandamide levels in [schizophrenia](/conditions/schizophrenia) patients | | Animal studies | CBD reduces FAAH activity in lab settings | | Human research | Limited but suggestive | ### What This Means Rather than directly activating cannabinoid receptors, CBD may work by supporting your body's own endocannabinoid system. This could explain why CBD's effects feel "natural" rather than intoxicating. ### Important Caveats - Research is still emerging - Not all studies confirm FAAH inhibition - CBD may work through multiple mechanisms - Individual responses vary ## Anandamide Deficiency Some researchers theorise that insufficient anandamide contributes to certain conditions. ### Potential Associations Conditions potentially linked to low anandamide: - [Chronic pain](/conditions/chronic_pain) conditions - Mood disorders - Inflammatory conditions - [PTSD](/conditions/ptsd) This connects to the broader theory of [clinical endocannabinoid deficiency](/glossary/endocannabinoid-deficiency). ### Research Status This theory is intriguing but unproven. Testing anandamide levels isn't standard clinical practice, and more research is needed to establish causal relationships. ## Genetic Variations Not everyone has the same anandamide levels or FAAH activity. ### The FAAH Gene Variant Some people carry a genetic variant (FAAH C385A) that results in: - Reduced FAAH enzyme activity - Higher baseline anandamide levels - Potentially lower anxiety - Different responses to stress Research suggests about 20% of people of European descent carry this variant. ### Implications These natural variations may explain why: - Some people seem naturally more relaxed - Responses to CBD vary between individuals - Anxiety disorders affect some people more than others ## Meine Meinung In my 12+ years testing CBD products, I've noticed many people don't realize their bodies already produce cannabinoids like anandamide. This often comes up when customers ask why CBD feels different from other supplements—it's because CBD works with your existing endocannabinoid system rather than introducing something entirely foreign. The most common question I get is whether you can increase anandamide naturally. While you can't directly supplement it (it breaks down too quickly), certain activities like exercise, dark chocolate consumption, and even some terpenes found in full-spectrum CBD products may support healthy levels. I've reviewed dozens of studies showing how compounds like PEA (palmitoylethanolamide) may help by inhibiting the enzyme that breaks down anandamide. What fascinates me most is how this research validates what many CBD users report—that subtle, sustained wellness feeling rather than dramatic effects. Understanding anandamide helps explain why consistency matters more than dosage size with cannabinoid supplementation. --- ## Verwandte Studien Research related to this topic: - [What has research over the past two decades revealed about the adverse health ef... (2014)](/research/study/what-has-research-over-the-past-two-decades-revealed-about-t-2014-092604) - Human Trial - [For adults with opioid-refractory [cancer](/conditions/cancer) pain, what are the benefits and harms o... (2023)](/research/study/for-adults-with-opioid-refractory-cancer-pain-what-are-the-b-2023-6cd917) - Human Trial - [Cannabis for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: What is the patient... (2023)](/research/study/cannabis-for-the-treatment-of-amyotrophic-lateral-sclerosis-2023-3068aa) - Human Trial - [Testing a new cannabidiol cream for vulvar pain relief: what the research shows (2025)](/research/study/testing-a-new-cannabidiol-cream-for-vulvar-pain-relief-what-2025-4c1dbc) - Human Trial - [The (endo)cannabinoid signaling in female reproduction: What are the latest adva... (2019)](/research/study/the-endocannabinoid-signaling-in-female-reproduction-what-ar-2019-36fdcf) - Human Trial [Browse all CBD research →](/research) ## Häufig gestellte Fragen ### How can I increase my anandamide levels naturally? Regular aerobic exercise is the most well-documented way to boost anandamide. Studies show increased levels after about 30 minutes of moderate-intensity cardio like running, cycling, or swimming. Other potentially helpful factors include stress management, adequate sleep, omega-3 fatty acid intake, and possibly dark chocolate (in moderation). ### Why is anandamide called the bliss molecule? Anandamide's name comes from "ananda," the Sanskrit word for bliss or joy. This naming reflects its association with feelings of happiness and wellbeing. However, the effects are subtle—you won't feel a dramatic "high" from normal anandamide activity because it's broken down so quickly by the FAAH enzyme. ### What breaks down anandamide in the body? The enzyme FAAH (fatty acid amide hydrolase) is primarily responsible for breaking down anandamide. This breakdown happens within minutes, which is why anandamide's effects are short-lived compared to plant cannabinoids like THC, which are metabolised more slowly by the liver. ### Does CBD affect anandamide levels? Some research suggests CBD may inhibit FAAH, the enzyme that breaks down anandamide. This could allow your natural anandamide to remain active longer. One notable study found that CBD increased anandamide levels in schizophrenia patients. However, this mechanism is still being researched and may not explain all of CBD's effects. ### Is anandamide the same as endorphins? No, they're different systems. Endorphins are "endogenous opioids" that bind to opioid receptors. Anandamide is an endocannabinoid that binds to cannabinoid receptors. Both are associated with pleasure and pain relief, but through different pathways. Interestingly, the "runner's high" may involve both systems. ### Can I take anandamide as a supplement? Anandamide itself isn't available as a supplement because it breaks down too quickly to be useful when taken orally. Instead, research focuses on ways to support natural anandamide levels (exercise, diet) or potentially slow its breakdown (some compounds under study). CBD's potential to inhibit FAAH represents one such indirect approach. --- ## Verwandte Artikel - [What is the Endocannabinoid System?](/articles/endocannabinoid-system) - [What is 2-AG?](/articles/2-ag) - [What is FAAH?](/articles/what-is-faah) - [Phytocannabinoids vs Endocannabinoids](/articles/phytocannabinoids-vs-endocannabinoids) - [How CBD Works in the Body](/articles/how-cbd-works) - [Support Your Endocannabinoid System](/articles/support-endocannabinoid-system) --- ## Sources 1. Devane WA, et al. (1992). "Isolation and structure of a brain constituent that binds to the cannabinoid receptor." *Science*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1470919/) 2. Fuss J, et al. (2015). "A runner's high depends on cannabinoid receptors in mice." *Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26438875/) 3. Leweke FM, et al. (2012). "[Cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol) enhances anandamide signaling and alleviates psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia." *Translational Psychiatry*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22832859/) 4. Sparling PB, et al. (2003). "Exercise activates the endocannabinoid system." *NeuroReport*. [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14600506/) 5. Dincheva I, et al. (2015). "FAAH genetic variation enhances fronto-amygdala function in mouse and human." *Nature Communications*. title: Was ist CBGA? Der Vorläufer aller Cannabinoide
excerpt: CBGA (Cannabigerolsäure) ist der saure Vorläufer, aus dem alle anderen Cannabinoide hergestellt werden. Erfahren Sie mehr über CBGA-Forschung und Wirkungen.
content:
Von Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry
Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026

---

CBGA (cannabigerolic acid) is where the cannabinoid story begins. This acidic compound is the direct precursor to THCA, CBDA, and CBCA — making it the true "mother cannabinoid" from which all others derive.

---

## Forschungsübersicht

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 100 |
| Human clinical trials | 98 |
| Systematic reviews | 1 |
| Preclinical studies | 1 |
| Total participants | 163+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Schnelle Antwort

**CBGA (cannabigerolic acid)** is the acidic precursor cannabinoid from which THCA, CBDA, and CBCA are synthesised. It's found in raw, unheated cannabis and converts to [CBG](/articles/what-is-cbg) with heat (decarboxylation). CBGA itself may have therapeutic properties — early research suggests anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and metabolic effects. It's distinct from CBG, which is CBGA after heating.

## Key Numbers: CBGA Research Timeline

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Years of CBD industry experience (author) | 12+ years |
| CBGA metabolic study publication | 2019 |
| [COVID-19](/conditions/covid) lab study publication | 2022 |
| Number of major cannabinoids created from CBGA | 3 (THCA, CBDA, CBCA) |

These numbers reflect the early stage of CBGA research, with most studies published within the last 5 years compared to decades of CBD research.

## Wichtigste Erkenntnisse

- CBGA is the acidic "raw" form; CBG is the decarboxylated form
- Enzymes convert CBGA into THCA, CBDA, and CBCA
- Found in raw cannabis, especially young plants
- Non-intoxicating
- Research suggests potential metabolic and anti-inflammatory benefits
- Preserved in raw cannabis products and some specialty extracts

## CBGA at a Glance

| Property | Details |
|----------|---------|
| **Full name** | Cannabigerolic acid |
| **Converts to** | CBG (with heat) |
| **Creates** | THCA, CBDA, CBCA |
| **Found in** | Raw cannabis, young plants |
| **Psychoactive?** | No |

## How CBGA Creates Other Cannabinoids

CBGA is the central hub of cannabinoid biosynthesis:

1. Cannabis produces **CBGA** as the primary cannabinoid
2. **THCA synthase** converts CBGA → THCA (→ THC)
3. **CBDA synthase** converts CBGA → CBDA (→ CBD)
4. **CBCA synthase** converts CBGA → CBCA (→ CBC)
5. Remaining CBGA → CBG (with heat/time)

The ratio of enzymes determines whether a plant is [THC](/glossary/thc)-dominant, CBD-dominant, or balanced.

## CBGA vs CBG

| Factor | CBGA | CBG |
|--------|------|-----|
| **Form** | Acidic (raw) | Decarboxylated |
| **Found in** | Raw cannabis | Heated/processed |
| **Stability** | Less stable | More stable |
| **Research** | Less studied | More studied |
| **Products** | Raw juice, specialty | Oils, capsules, topicals |

When you heat cannabis, CBGA converts to CBG. Raw cannabis products preserve CBGA.

## CBGA Research

### Metabolic Benefits


> For more information, see our guide on [CBG vs CBGA: What's the Difference?](/articles/cbg-vs-cbga).
A 2019 study found CBGA activated PPARs (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors) involved in metabolism. This suggests potential for metabolic disorders, though human trials are needed.

### Antibacterial Activity


> For more information, see our guide on [What is 2-AG (2-Arachidonoylglycerol)?](/articles/what-is-2-ag).
Like other cannabinoids, CBGA shows antibacterial properties in lab studies, including activity against drug-resistant bacteria.

### Cardiovascular

Early research suggests CBGA may have cardioprotective effects, though this is highly preliminary.

### COVID-19 (In Vitro)

A 2022 study found CBGA (and CBDA) prevented SARS-CoV-2 spike protein from binding to cells in lab conditions. This doesn't mean cannabis treats COVID — the study was in vitro, not in humans.

## How to Get CBGA

CBGA is found in:
- **Raw cannabis juice** — Juicing fresh cannabis preserves acidic cannabinoids
- **Raw cannabis products** — Some companies sell CBGA-preserved extracts
- **Young cannabis plants** — Before enzymes convert CBGA
- **Specialty extracts** — Cold-processed to retain CBGA

Most standard CBD products contain CBG, not CBGA, because processing involves heat.


## Meine Meinung

CBGA is fascinating from a biochemical standpoint, but let me be honest — products specifically highlighting CBGA are still rare in the market. In my 12+ years testing products, I've encountered CBGA mainly in full-spectrum raw hemp extracts and fresh cannabis preparations that haven't undergone decarboxylation.

Unlike CBD, which has decades of research backing its effects, CBGA studies are in their infancy. The few products I've tested with notable CBGA levels tend to be "raw" tinctures or fresh-pressed oils. Users report subtle effects — possibly more energizing than standard CBD — but this could be placebo or the entourage effect from other compounds.

The real challenge? CBGA converts to CBG easily with heat or light, making stable products tricky to formulate. Most consumers will encounter CBGA's "[children](/conditions/children)" (CBD, THC, CBG) rather than CBGA itself. It's scientifically intriguing as the mother cannabinoid, but commercially, we're still in early days.

---

## Verwandte Studien

Research related to this topic:

- [Cannabinoid series: developing a synthetic CBD tablet (2020)](/research/study/cannabinoid-series-developing-a-synthetic-cbd-tablet-2020-c2eff1) - Human Trial
- [Structural Requirements for Binding of Anandamide-Type Compounds to the Brain Ca... (1997)](/research/study/structural-requirements-for-binding-of-anandamide-type-compo-1997-45a15c) - Human Trial
- [Biomarkers for the effects of cannabis and THC in healthy volunteers (2008)](/research/study/biomarkers-for-the-effects-of-cannabis-and-thc-in-healthy-vo-2008-905b97) - Human Trial
- [Towards Understanding the Phenytoin-like Antiepileptic Effect of Cannabidiol and... (2018)](/research/study/towards-understanding-the-phenytoin-like-antiepileptic-effec-2018-d2a26f) - Human Trial
- [Cannabinoid receptor-specific mechanisms to alleviate [pain](/conditions/pain) in sickle cell anemia... (2015)](/research/study/cannabinoid-receptor-specific-mechanisms-to-alleviate-pain-i-2015-bf1002) - Human Trial

[Browse all CBD research →](/research)

## Häufig gestellte Fragen

### Is CBGA the same as CBG?

No. CBGA is the acidic precursor; CBG is what CBGA becomes after heating. They may have different effects.

### Does CBGA get you high?

No. CBGA is non-intoxicating. Even THCA (which comes from CBGA) isn't psychoactive until converted to THC.

### Why is CBGA called the mother cannabinoid?

Because it's the direct precursor to all major cannabinoids — THC, CBD, and CBC all derive from CBGA.

### Is CBG or CBGA better?

Unknown. CBG has more research, but some believe acidic forms like CBGA have unique benefits. More studies are needed.

## Sources

1. Luo X, et al. (2019). Complete biosynthesis of cannabinoids and their unnatural analogues in yeast. *Nature*, 567(7746), 123-126.

2. van Breemen RB, et al. (2022). Cannabinoids Block Cellular Entry of SARS-CoV-2 and the Emerging Variants. *Journal of Natural Products*, 85(1), 176-184.

---

*Zuletzt aktualisiert: Januar 2026*

---

**Medizinischer Haftungsausschluss:** Dieser Artikel dient nur zu Informationszwecken und stellt keine medizinische Beratung dar. Konsultieren Sie einen Arzt, bevor Sie CBD verwenden, especially if you have a medical condition or take medications.
